on April 13th I paid 2l. more, making 10l.; bat the receipts amounted to 10l. 15l.—I do not know what the 15s. is for—I commenced my duty on 26th March—I went, at Stanley's direction, to the Thames Tunnel, and made inquiry respecting some premises that were to let by an advertisement out of the paper—he said I was to inquire in my own name, and on no pretence to let them know it was a house-agent inquiring—I afterwards had several letters addressed to me, from the different parties of whom I inquired—I asked Sparks his name, and wrote it down in this book (prodeced),"Sydney Sparks," but Stanley told me Sparks's name was Spinks—I received orders two or three time from Sparks, and once or twice from a little boy, I believe under Stanley, and from Stanley himself—I never saw Campbell or Wright at Kingsgate-street—in consequence of what another prisoner told me (I do not know whether he is now in Court), I went to Brownlow-street two or three times, and once found Stanley and Campbell there, talking, with papers on the table—on two occasions I found Campbell there, and once a man named Long, who I found was another dupe of them, and who I believe is a witness to-day—I was in the service three or four weeks—I received 10s. at the end of the first week—my wages were to be 2l. a week—on the second Saturday there was some offered me by a young man—I said I would not leave without seeing Stanley, and he came forward—on the Monday following I received 15s., and a day or two after 1l. from Stanley—I have applied to him several times, and have not been able to get any more—I have tried to come to terms with him to give me part of the money, and he has appointed to meet me at certain hours, and has never kept the appointments—when I complained of walking about so much, he said he would put me in another house he had in the Strand.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Are you a member of the committee? A. No; there was one, to get together the young men who had been duped, and to get evidence—I do not recollect Sparks being away from the office some time—when I met him, he looked very ill, and was obliged to walk with a stick, and he was given into custody—I was to pay 15l. deposit, and 1l. for the agreement—I paid 10l., and the rest was to be taken out of my wages at 2s. 6d. a week.

HEBER GOING LOTEN . I am a mariner, and live at Artichoke-place, Mile-end-road. In consequence of an answer to an advertisement in the paper, I went to 3, Kingsgate-street, about 20th or 25th March—I saw Stanley, who told me the situation was in his own office, and the salary would be 2l. a week—I said I was unacquainted with business, and was willing to take a smaller salary—he said he could not think of offering me a smaller salary than that—he said I should have to pay 10l., and I left a deposit of 10s., as binding me to the situation—I was to pay the rest on entering the situation on 1st April—I went on 1st April, and paid 9l. 10s. in gold—Stanley stated when I first saw him, that he would have an agreement properly drawn up, his legal man should draw it up—when I paid the money, Sparks, who was acting as the legal man, produced the agreement and read it over at Stanley's wish—I read it over, and fetched a witness on my part—the legal man was gone then—this is the agreement (prodeced)—after that Stanley asked me if I had any particular inclination to go to Greenwich fair—I said certainly, and he gave me two days' holiday to go—on the Wednesday I re
turned to the office at ten, and found the shutters closed—I returned at half-past ten or eleven, and found Sparks sitting behind the desk—he told me Mr. Stanley had been called by urgent business out of town—before that, I had seen Stanley and Sparks in the street together, and I saw Stanley again about

two o'clock—on my going on the Thursday, Stanley told me, in consequence of a person not having left them who he thought would, I might extend my holiday to the following Monday—I went on the Monday, and was sent to inquire the rent and examine some houses down by the Surrey Zoological Gardens—I was to do it in my own name, on no account to mention Mr. Stanley, or to say I came from an agency office—after that, I was sent with letters directed with initials—in consequence of what a cousin of mine told me, I went to Mr. Campbell's office in Brownlow-street, and saw Campbell there, and a son of Sparks—I had seen Stanley at the door but not inside—I remained in the employment a fortnight—this I O U for 4l. 5s., 18th April, is 4l. for two weeks salary, and 5s. which I charged for omnibuses, that is all I received in the shape of money—Mr. Stanley gave me 2s. when Mr. Henry discharged him—I went to Kingsgate-street office on 20th April—I was sent out with some letters, and when I returned, Morris, who was there, told me Stanley had gone to Southampton—I searched the house to see if I could find him, and the most valuable article I found was an old pewter pot—I went to Mr. Campbell's office, Brownlow-street, the same day, and saw Stanley coming out—it was No. 7, a Loan, Investment, and Emigration Office—I asked him if he intended paying me—he said he was particularly sorry; really it was not in his power that day—I saw him again the same day at Nixon and Co's., 79, Great Queen-street, and when he saw me and one or two other victims, he ran into a back-room—George was with me—we made a disturbance—this (produced—headed "Loan Discount and Guarantee Office") is one of the prospectuses of the Kingsgate-street establishment.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Were not Stanley's words that he would have an agreement drawn up by a legal man? A. Yes; I signed my name, and paid the money when Sparks was not there—I took Stanley before Mr. Hall, and he dismissed the charge—I charged him with obtaining money by false pretences—there was no evidence gone into, except the reading of my agreement—I was one of the St. Martin's-lane Committee—we met to raise funds.

The Defendant WRIGHT here pleaded
GUILTY .

JAMES BURGH LONG . I live at Brompton, and am a clerk. On 4th or 5th April, in consequence of an answer to advertisement I inserted on 3rd, I went to the "Loan, Investment, and Emigration Office, 7, Brownlow-street"—I saw Sparks and Campbell—I showed Sparks the letter I had received with refer
ence to the advertisement, and he referred me to Campbell—Sparks asked me whether I was prepared with security—I said I was, with either personal or cash—he said, "Our manager will not take personal security"—I only knew him as Mr. Sydney—Campbell then had no moustachios or imperial—on the first interview, after conversing about the duties of the place, he asked me whether I was prepared to pay some deposit as security—I said yes—he asked what money I had—I said 2l.—he said he wanted 10l. to buy the situation—I said I had not got it about me, I would let him have the two sovereigns, and go to the bank for more—I gave him the two sovereigns, went to the bank, then gave him eight more, and he gave me a receipt—Sparks was in and out of the office—this is the receipt for the 10l. (produced)—the body of it is in Sparks's writing, and the signature is Campbell's—I paid Campbell 40l. more by a check on the Monday, and he gave me this receipt (prodeced)—it is all in his writing—I have lost my agreement, thiss is the counter-part of it (produced by Thompson)—I signed two—I kept one and he one—I had to go out and make inquiries at various places, generally at a great distance off—I remained a fortnight—I got 2l. the first week, and none

after that—Sparks was there at the beginning of the first week, but not at the latter end—he acted as head clerk—I saw Stanley and Wright there on two or three occasions—I went on the second Saturday, 20th April—I found no one there but an old man, who had been there three or four days, and goes by the name of Mack; I have not seen him since—on one occasion I saw Stanley in the private room with Campbell nearly an hour.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you produce your agreement before the Magistrate? A. Yes; I did not afterwards refuse to produce if—I last saw it when I was in the witness-box—I missed it next day—I thought I put it into my pocket-book—there was not anything upon it which I did not like to be seen—I have not lost my pocket-book—I was very indignant when I found the old man at the office—I went into the private room—I did not break the door open—I pushed the door, and Mack's arm gave way—I did say I would break every bone in Campbell when I found him—I did not say I would break the place down—I wrote a notice, and left it on the table—I said if he would give me the 40l. I would take that—he did not say I had disgraced myself by my violent conduct, and I had better leave at once—an appointment was made to meet Campbell at his solicitors that evening—I afterwards went to the office with Loten, my cousin—there was a woman there; we did not insult her—we put placards all about the place; we did not paint out the writing—the placards did not hide the name of the office—we did not take away any papers—I did not take a lot of memorandums, and say I would have them, they belonged as much to me as them—once when I went to the office, I was told Campbell had gone to Brighton—I did not receive any money from persons who came to the office—the only business I did was to date a few letters signed by Campbell, and the only money I received was 2d. for a prospectus.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You paid the 10l. and the 40l. to Campbell? A. Yes, I do not recollect Campbell calling Sparks in from the outer office—both times that I went about the situation, Sparks kept coming in and out—Sparks always gave me the inquiry papers—after the first day, Campbell never spoke to me about my business—I never said that Sparks acted under Campbell's instructions; he appeared to be a clerk; he was absent some days, and some one in the office said he was ill of a liver-complaint; when I was with Loten and George I met him, and said he looked ill—I requested him to go home and go to bed, and I told him when he was well would be time enough for me to bring my charge against him—I am a member of the committee to inquire and get evidence—I am sorry to say we got very few—I do not know their names—none of them are here—I think we got six.

MR. PARNELL. Q. Are there any witnesses to-day that were not wit
nesses before Mr. Jardine when the prisoners were committed? A. No.

THOMAS SAUNDERS . I am a carpenter, and know all the prisoners. About 24th March I fitted up an office for Wright, at 17, Adam-street, Adelphi—he was to pay me 6s.—I was there on 8th April, and recollect Topp coming to see Wright, who then whispered to me, asked me to leave the office a few moments, said he was going to nail him, and then he would pay me—I left, went again, and asked for my money—he said he had not received it yet, he was going to take him on trial, he would have it in the course of a week—on 22nd April I was introduced to Stanley by young Wright, who said, "This is Mr. Saunders; I think he is a person who can do your business for you"—Stanley said he had an office in Great Queen-street, and he had seen a young man, an auctioneer, from the country, and had received a sovereign from him, and was going to receive 9l. on the following morning—

he gave me a description of him which agrees with Pascall, who was after
wards pointed out to me—Stanley said his office was too hot for him, and I was to go in and mind it on his behalf, take an extract from the Times, and send him with it, and keep the clerks as quiet as I could, and hinder them from touching any of the papers or books there—I went next day—Pascall came, and I took an extract from the Times, and sent him to Bayswater—I saw Stanley the same evening at the Old Bell, in Wellington-street, and told him what I had done—he said it was quite right—Loten and George also came to the office, and I told them it was all a trick, they would never get their money—I remained there till the Friday, when I gave the keys to Mr. Parrott, the landlord—while I was there, Stanley sent me to Brownlow-street—I went and saw a lady, and said I had a message from Mr. Stanley to Mr. Campbell—Campbell was in the back-parlour, and could hear what I said—I said, "Mr. Stanley tells me to tell you that party you have had 50l. from is getting rather troublesome, and you had better keep out of the way"—he said, "Very well, tell him I am very much obliged to him"—I was in Wright's service three weeks altogether—he told me his method of business was of advertising in the Times for young men wanting situations, and making appointments with them half-an-hour after each other—he said the first thing was to get the deposits, or part of them—he said, "When any reference is wanted about respectability, I send to Brownlow-street, and Brownlow-street sends to me"—I saw a man at Wright's office named James, who I know by sight—I heard him say, "I tell you what it is; my office is too hot for me and yours for you; the best way is for me to take your place a little time till it is blown over"—I saw Sparks the day after I gave up the keys, and he said I was a d—d fool to give up the keys, and "I would not have cared a pin if the papers were all right"—Wright told me he was obliged to let Mr. Campbell have a sovereign, because the carpenter was kicking up a row about the blinds at Brownlow-street.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were you sent to sea by your family? A. Yes; it was not for stealing from my father; I had a predilec
tion for the sea—I was at sea four years—I was Queen's evidence in a case against some men about town for taking some property from Chaplin and Home's—I got 25l. for that—I never borrowed 3l. or 1l. on any 50l.-note, or promissory-note, or any bill—Mr. Jardine was the only Magistrate before whom I was examined—I do not expect to get anything for coming here—I sold a person a receipt for making French-polish for 3l.—I did not for that promise to get a stolen 50l.-note—I never had a stolen note, or knew anybody with one.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Since you were first examined, how many places have you lived in? A. Two; I went away without paying rent, I was not asked for it—I pay 4s. a week—I get my money by working for it at Mr. Neale's, the pianoforte-makers—I have been in constant employ for three months—I have been twice charged with felony—I was never charged with robbing my father—I was charged first with taking a duplicate from a man's pocket—I was acquitted—the second time I was charged with taking things from a furnished lodging—I was discharged—it was after that that I was Queen's evidence.
MR. PARNELL. Q. When was this about Chaplin and Home's? A. Last Oct.; the directors of the South Western Railway paid me the'money—one of the parties was transported, and the other had six months.
THOMAS TOPP . I am a servant. I made an agreement with Wright on 5th April to go into his service—I paid 3l., and got back 10s.—on 28th

April I went to a public-house next door to the Adelphi theatre, and there saw Sparks, Wright, Stanley, and two or three others—a person named Pen
nington was one of them—I asked Wright for my money back—they said it was not worth coming after—Pennington gave me a slap on the face, and Stanley was for putting me out of the house—on 14th May, I saw Stanley and James in Wigmore-street—I followed them, and James said to Stanley, "That is one of Wright's victims for 3l."—Stanley said that paltry sum was not worth noticing; if he was taken before a hundred Magistrates he would meet them all, for they were all a set of d—fools, and did not know common law—he said if any of them asked him for money, he would set to and give them a good milling, and pitch into them like a brick, as he had to one the day before—I asked if they could tell me where Wright was, and James said if I would stand something to drink, they would, but they roust be d—d fools to tell where the others were, for nothing.

WILLIAM PARROTT . I live at 7, Princes-street, Drury-lane. I had the letting of 79, Great Queen-street, and let it to Sparks on Thursday, 15th April—I have an agreement dated 18th April, which he signed—the house was opened on the following Monday, in the name of "Nixon and Co."—on Saturday 27th, I received the keys from Saunders—I found in the house a quantity of papers, which I delivered to Serjeant Thompson.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You let the house to Sparks, and he did not come near it for some time? A. I saw him there on the Thursday—he paid me 1l. 12s.—I was sent for on the Monday, because there were a quantity of young men round the place—Sparkes seemed poorly on the Thursday, and I did not see him again for ten days, when he applied for the papers—I did not give them him, and he took out a summons against me to Bow-street, where he was taken into custody.

WILLIAM PASCALL . I was an auctioneer in the country. In consequence of an advertisement, on 20th April I went to 79, Great Queen-street, where there was "Nixon and Co." up—I saw a person of the name of Nixon—the tall prisoner is the man (Stanley)—he was dressed in Californian trowsers, and I have seen him wear spectacles—I was engaged by him as his clerk and messenger, and agreed to pay him a deposit of 10l.—I paid him 1l. that day, and 9l. on the following Tuesday—I executed this agreement (prodeced)—I commenced my duties on Saturday the 20th, remained until the Tuesday, and on Wednesday morning found it was all up—I saw Saunders there, and he sent me to three or four different places, Kensington, Bayswater, and so on—I afterwards saw Stanley at the White Horse, in Theobald's-road, and asked him for my money back—he made an appointment for me to call there on the following Saturday at exactly three o'clock—I went, and did not find him there—I know the other prisoners by seeing them at the office, and in each other's company—I have seen Wright in Stanley's company.

JOSEPH THOMPSON (police-sergeant, F 11). I took Campbell, Sparks, and Stanley into custody—I took Stanley at 15, Blandford-street, Dorset-square, a loan and discount-office—he was then going in the name of Harvey—I there found these circulars relating to the office (prodeced)—there is no name signed to them—they are precisely the same as the Brownlow-street ones, except that Brownlow-street is altered to Blandford-street—I found some books, papers, and about 100 letters—I went to Brownlow-street, and there found a great many letters, papers, and a diary—in the diary on 30th March there is this entry, "Mr. James to call at one o'clock, 10l.; paid Gun on account, out of gull-fund, 1l."—I received a number of papers from Mr. Parrott, of which these are some (prodeced)—there is a letter among them

from a young man claiming a return of money, and some agreements, the same as those produced, except that the person who enters into the agree
ment is Sparks—I took Sparks in Russell-street, Bow-street, and found the letter produced on him—at Stanley's office, in Queen-street, I found a quantity of papers, and among them a letter from a Mrs. Curtis (prodeced), and this prospectus of the Kingsgate-street office, stating that money orders were to be made payable in favour of Robert Sparks.

Stanley's Defence. I have been taken into custody two or three times; I was discharged the first time at Bow-street, and the second before Mr. Henry, who said there was no charge against me; the parties then got up a meeting at St. Martin's-lane, concocted this charge against us, and brought us before Mr. Jardine; I am prepared at this moment to settle with them.

WRIGHT— GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

CAMPBELL—
GUILTY . Aged 37.

STANLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

SPARKS—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoners.)

1184.
EDWARD WRIGHT, senior, and
JOHN JAMES
, unlawfully obtaining 10l., the moneys of
William Davies, by false pretences.—2nd COUNT, for a conspiracy. EDWARD WRIGHT pleaded
GUILTY* to 2nd Count. Aged 57.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

WILLIAM DAVIES . I am a civil engineer, and live at Denton-street, St. Pancras. At the end of Nov., in consequence of an advertisement, I went to 447, Oxford-street, and there saw Wright, who engaged me as his clerk—I was to make a deposit of 10l., for money that had to pass through my hands—I deposited 1l. that day, and 9l. the second—I believe that was 24th Nov.—my salary was to commence from 1st Dec.—the first day I went, I was sent a long way out to look at houses, and when I came back I was told I had nothing to do—the next day I went to another part of the town at a distance—when the week was out, I applied for my salary, and did not get any—Wright's card was "Wright and Co.," and "Wright and Co." was over the door—he told me James, Sparks and Campbell were his partners—after I had paid him the 10l., I was out with him, and we met James in New Oxfords street, and Wright said, "This is Mr. James my partner"—James heard that—Wright gave him two sovereigns, and said, "It is the two out of the 10l. I have received of Davies; that will be your share"—James took it, and they went away together—I have seen James and Wright, and applied to them for my money—I have not been able to get it.

James. Q. When was it you saw me in New Oxford-street? A. I think 24th Nov.; it was before I commenced the business—I do not know whether I told the Magistrate that Wright paid you 2l.—you were not in custody.

JAMES—
GUILTY on 2nd Count.—
Confined Eighteen Months.
(There was another indictment against James.)

1185.
JOHN GODDARD
, stealing 1 jacket, value 5s.; the goods of
Joseph Robert Gay: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Four Months.

1186.
ROBERT SMITH,
JOHN FOSTER , and
DAVID ALLEN
, stealing 7 tame ducklings, price 5s.; the property of
Mary Ward: to which

SMITH pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 16.

FOSTER pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 17.
(They received good characters.)

JOHN DOHERTY (policeman, N 151). On the 20th May I was on duty in Black Horse-lane, Walthamstow—I met the three prisoners—Smith had a basket containing these seven ducks—I took Smith and Foster, and Allen ran away—Mrs. Ward identified the ducks.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Are you quite sure that Allen was not in advance of the others? A. He was when he came up to me, but they had all been in a line before.
MARY WARD . I am t widow, and live at Walthamstow. On the 20th May I had these ducks safe in my yard, I missed them at night—the officer brought them next morning—they were mine.

JOHN FOSTER (the prisoner.) I went with the other prisoners on Whit-Monday, on the Forest—in coming back we saw these ducks in the pond—Smith proposed to have them—I said, "Very well"—Allen did not say any
thing, but he walked on—I took the ducks, and Smith helped me—Allen had got about five minutes' walk before us—we caught him again, and walked on.

ALLEN—
NOT GUILTY .

1187.
ELIZABETH BRADY
, stealing 1 half-crown and 1 sixpence; the moneys of
William Ingram.

CHARLES STOKES . About seven o'clock in the evening, on 30th May, the prisoner came into my master's shop, Mr. William Ingram, at Barking-side—she asked for 7lbs, of salt—I went into the warehouse for it, and left her in the shop—I came back in about two minutes, and heard the silver in the till rattle, and saw the key of the till swinging—I accused the prisoner of robbing the till—she had her right hand closed, and her left hand down by her side—I took from her right hand a half-crown and a sixpence, and said I would give her in charge—she then said, "I took it"—this is the half-crown; I made a mark on it before my governor gave it to the policeman—there had been two half-crowns in the till before, this and another, a new one—after I took this from her hand there was one in the till.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. This was long before you saw the policeman? A. Yes; there was about 30s. in the till—there was this half-crown and another—I went to the till after I had taken this from her hand, and found one half-crown and about 30s.—I did not count it—I cannot tell whether any money was missing—I had known her before; we were not sweethearts—she was married last Christmas—I was not very angry when she got married—she did not lay a half-crown down on the counter, or on the salt—nothing passed between us, and she did not say she would tell my master.

JOSEPH POOLE (policeman, K 374). I was called, and took the prisoner—she asked what I wanted—I told her Mr. Ingram charged her with stealing a half-crown and a sixpence—she said, "I own I took the half-crown; the sixpence belonged to me"—this is the half-crown.
NOT GUILTY .

1188.
JOHN HOME
, stealing 3lbs, of lamb, and 1 3/4lbs. of mutton, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Richard Hancock;
also 2 pairs of boots, and 1 pair of shoes, value 8s.; the goods of
William Marchant: to which he pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 30.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutors. —

1189.
ELIZA WYATT
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 7d.; the goods of
Robert Roughton, her master: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1190.
HENRY PAYNE
, stealing 1 carpenter's tool, called a plough, value 5s.; the goods of
William Thomas James; and 1 other tool, value 14s.; the property of
David Brown: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.

1191.
THOMAS RILEY
, stealing 5 loaves of bread, and 1/4 peck of flour, value 1s. 10d.; the goods of
Benjamin Porter: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Two Months.

1192.
WILLIAM WOOD
, stealing 4 pewter pots, value 6s.; the goods of
Edward Winn.

ANN NICHOLLS . I am single; I live with Mr. Winn, who keeps the Nile public-house, at Greenwich. On the morning of 8th June, I saw the prisoner in the yard—he took a pewter-pot and went into the closet—I told my master.

EDWARD WINN . Nicholls told me of this, and I went down stairs, and watched the prisoner—I saw him come out of the closet, and he folded his coat over—he went into the tap-room—I sent for a constable, went to the closet from which the prisoner came, and found there these four pots which are mine—they had before been in the yard close to the tap-room door.
HENRY HICKS (policeman, R 102). I took the prisoner—I told him what I took him for—he said he had been guilty of no such thing—the pots are bent.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to the water-closet and saw these pots in the closet.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

1193.
JAMES GIBSON , was indicted
for embezzlement.

CATHERINE CONNELL . I am a widow, and carry on the business of a farmer and milk-dealer at Plumstead. The prisoner was my carter—he came at 14s. a week, and it was changed to 12s., as he did not suit me—I sent him to Mr. Silverlock with a load of breese—I gave him the account, and authorised him to receive the money—he said Mr. Silverlock would send his gardener to pay the amount—he went afterwards with other loads, and brought the same answer.

JAMES SPOONER . I paid the prisoner 1l. on 13th Feb., on account of Mr. Silverlock for Mrs. Connell—I received the receipt from the prisoner, he marked it in my presence—he offered to bring me a load of breese if I could get the money to spend for beer.
Prisoner. My mistress gave me the bills for Mr. Silverlock and Captain

Bailey; I got the money and lost it from my pocket; I thought to make the money op and pay the sovereign; I expected some money every day from a brother; I told my mistress I lost it, and that I would pay it at so much a week.
CATHERINE CONNELL (re-examined.) He did not tell me till after he was in charge on 10th May, and the money was paid on 13th Feb.

GUILTY . Aged 47.—
Confined Three Months.

1194.
PATRICK MURPHY
, stealing 12 pairs of braces, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Vowell.

HENRY BURNS (policeman, R 261). I was on duty near the Ravensboun river, at Greenwich, on 23rd May—I saw the prisoner coming towards me—I saw he had something under his jacket—I asked what he had got—he refused to tell me—I said I could not let him pass till be had told me—he took this parcel from under his jacket and threw it over a wall, fourteen feet high—one pair dropped at his feet—I took him to the station—I came back and found the parcel—it contained these twelve pairs of braces.

THOMAS VOWELL . I live at Blackheath-hill, and keep a shop. These braces are mine—I had missed them one or two days before the policeman brought them to my shop, which was about an hour and a half after he took the prisoner—they have my mark on them—they had been on a shelf at the back of the shop.

Prisoner. I had them but a few minutes in my possession, when the police
man took me; I was drunk at the time, and when I get drunk I am rather obstinate, but I never stole anything in my life; I wanted the officer to bring up the other man, and he would not.

HENRY BURNS
re-examined. He had been drinking, but was not drunk—he was nearly a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's—there was another man with him, and he ran away when he saw me take the prisoner—the Magistrate said he thought it was not proper to take that man, but he offered the prisoner a summons to get the man if he liked.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Three Months.

1195.
GEORGE SCOTT
, stealing 5 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Chambers.
JANE CHAMBERS . I am the wife of Thomas Chambers. I hung out these stockings on 29th May, and missed them on the 30th.

JOHN WALKER (policeman, R 298). On 30th May, I was on duty in Beresford-street, Woolwich—I met the prisoner, and asked what he had in his bundle—he said, "Nothing"—I took it, and found a tame duck and a tame drake in it—I found these stockings concealed under his coat—he was about five minutes' walk from the place where the stockings were hung out.
Prisoner. One man gave me the ducks, and another the stockings.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner).

1196.
GEORGE SPARK
, stealing 2 sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, 12 shil
lings, and 1 sixpence; the moneys of
James Laing.

JAMES LAING . I am a corporal in the Artillery at Woolwich. On 2nd May, I had two sovereigns, two half-crowns, twelve shillings, and a sixpence in a purse in my box at No. 116 barrack-room—the box was locked—I put it under the bed, and put the key in the fold of the blanket—I went on duty

at a quarter-past eight o'clock—I came back at a quarter before twelve—the prisoner bad charge of the barrack-room—I left him there when I went on duty; when I came back, he was absent—I went to my box, and the purse and money were gone—the prisoner continued absent till 8th May—he was taken before the officers—I was there—he said he would speak the truth, he had taken the money to the amount of 2l. 10s.—no one said it would be better for him to tell, he was merely asked if he knew anything about it.

DAVID SIMPER (policeman, R 310). I received charge of the prisoner at the station—he said he took the money, and on going to the lock-up place, he said he took the money from the box—I asked what he had done with it—he said he spent it at Greenwich.

Prisoner's Defence. A friend came to see me, who enticed me to go out to drink; I got too much, and absented myself for six days; I then gave myself up to the sergeant of the guard; the sergeant-major came to me, and asked if I had spent all the money; I said, "What money?" he said, "You will be made to know," and the next day I was ordered before the Colonel, who asked me if I would be tried by a Court-martial for selling my regi
mental boots, and the next day I was called and asked if I knew anything about Corporal Laing's money; I told him I did take it, but I solemaly declare I know nothing about it; I did not know what I was doing or saying, for I was not in my reason, being afraid of being flogged; I thought it better to throw myself on the civil Court, and should I be so fortunate as to be acquitted, I intend, by God's assistance, to. be a good soldier, and not swerve from the duties of my calling.
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Six Months.
(The prosecutor stated that the prisoner had been tried by three Courts-martial.)

1197.
ROBERT MATTISON was indicted
for embezzling 16 shilling; the moneys of
Charles Edward Matson, his master.

CHARLES FRANCIS GALE . I am a solicitor. On 29th May, I was return
ing from the Derby—I saw the prisoner, who was acting as guard to one of the coaches—I asked him for two places for myself and a friend—he spoke to some persons, and we were allowed to get on the box, but it was agreed that if a passenger returned, one should get on the roof—it was not agreed then what I should pay the prisoner, but on the road home it was, and I paid him 16s., that was 8s. a piece for myself and friend before I arrived in town—Church was the coachman.

EDWARD WILLIAM CHURCH . I am in the service of Charles Edward Matson—on the Derby-day I was at Epsom—I drove the coach to which the prisoner was acting as guard—I did not know of any extra passengers—I did not see Mr. Gale taken on the coach—I did not receive any money from him—I received a sovereign from the prisoner previous to going in the morn
ing—I did not receive any money for passengers taken at Epsom—if he took any money be did not pay it me.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Who paid Mr. Matson the fare of the passengers? A. I paid it to Mrs. Matson the same night—I received part of the fares—we generally drink a good deal on the Derby-day, and more in coming back than in going—I had seen the prisoner before, but had no personal knowledge of him—when these new passengers were taken up, the prisoner did not ask me, and tell me about them—he came to the side of the carriage, and said, would I take up one for 6s.—I said, "Yes; put them inside at what price you like"—in coming home, I turned to the pri
soner, and asked him to collect my money of the back passengers, but I did

not know but that they were the same party I had taken up in the morning who had paid their fares there, I believe—the prisoner paid me a sovereign in the morning, and I gave him 4s. back—I stopped at the World Tamed Upside-down to refresh my horses, and to ascertain the expenses—the prisoner was there drinking—I had been drinking a good deal—I was a little fresh, and so was the prisoner.

COURT. Q. How many passengers did you take down?A. Twelve out
side and one in—they all paid their fare there and back again before they separated.

MR. COOPER. Q. Are you quite sure you could have told at night whe
ther you had not received the money from this man? A. Such a thing might have taken place, but not to the best of my knowledge—I will swear he did not to the best of my knowledge—if there had been any money afterwards, I must have known it in the cash.
NOT GUILTY .

1198.
JAMES PADGETT
, stealing 1 shilling, 2 pence, and 1 halfpenny, the moneys of
Alicia Woodman; from her person: having been before con
victed; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1199.
ROBERT HILL and
GEORGE KIMPTON
, stealing 1 bowl, value 1s.; 2 shillings, 2 sixpences, 8 groats, and 4 pence, the property of
Stephen Henry Green: Hill having been before convicted.

AUGUSTA AMELIA LOUISA GREEN . I am between twelve and thirteen years old, and live with my father Stephen Henry Green, who keeps the Red Lion in the Greenwich-road. On a Thursday evening in May, the prisoners came there and asked for a pint of potter—I served them, and they took it to Mr. Colson's, the fishmongers—about a minute or two after, I heard a noise, went into the bar-parlour, and saw Hill on his hands and knees just coming away from the till, and Kimpton standing outside the bar—they both ran away—I saw some farthings lying about the bar which were not there when I left two or three minutes before—the silver bowl in the till was gone—I think there were two shillings, six or seven fourpenny-pieces, and two or three sixpences in it, and there were some farthings gone from another bowl—I called my mother.

GEORGE KING . I am a miller, in the service of Mr. Mumford, of 3, Frances-street, Deptford. On 9th May, about a quarter-past eleven o'clock, I was standing at the mill-gate, which is twenty yards from Mr. Green's, and saw two boys come out from there, and run past me—Kimpton was one, and he had something hollow in his hand, with something in it which glistened very much—I did not observe the other boy.
Kimpton. Q. How do you swear to me? A. By the appearance of your face—I saw you again a week after—I heard a complaint from the prosecutor, three or four minutes after.

GEORGE BENSOR (policeman, R 22). I received information—I found the pri
soners at a coffee-shop in Church-street—I asked both of them where they came from—they said, "From London"—I asked what money they had—Hill produced one shilling, six 4d.-pieces, and a farthing, and Kimpton one shilling, two 4d.-pieces, and 4 1/2d. in copper—I asked where they got it—they said they earnt it at the "Waterman's Pier" by carrying parcels—I asked if they had been in any public-house—they said, "No"—I brought them to Mr. Green, and they were identified—the bowl was afterwards brought back.
JOHN CARPENTER (policeman, R 38). I produce a certificate—(read—Robert Hill, Convicted Sept. 1849, and confined six months)—I was present—Hill is the person—he had been sumarily convicted before.

HILL—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years.

KIMPTON—
GUILTY .*† Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months and
Whipped.

1200.
THOMAS SABIN,
HENRY FETHERSTON,
DENNY FETHERSTON, JUN. ,
JEREMIAH REEVES,
PETER GOULD,
STEPHEN TOMS,
SAMUEL TUBBY , and
JAMES PEARSON , were in
dicted for
a forcible entry.

JACOB SMITH . I am a farm-servant of Mr. Stephen Sabin, of Lewisham, the prosecutor. On 7th May, about a quarter-past six o'clock in the morning, I saw Reeves come over our yard gate, followed by young Fetherstone, Gould, Toms, Tubby, and Pearson, and they went into the stable—my master came out, and ordered them off, telling them they bad no business there—I heard Gould say they were there for 150l. rent—about half-past six, Sabin came in towards the stable—Gould met him, and spoke to him—he turned back, and I did not see him any more that day—Gould came back again—the elder Fetherston was there next day—they remained in the stable, in and out, till eight in the evening when my master, Mr. Turner, and Wallis went in, and master asked who was the broker's son—the men pointed him out, and master took hold of his collar and turned him out—the other men got between them in a cluster, and one of them knocked master's hat off—I could not see who it was—Tubby held up a stick, and said he would knock the first man down that came near him—one of them, I do not know which, pulled off his gloves and put up his hands, as if he meant to fight—we then left the stable, and left them there all night—next morning, about eight, I heard the elder Fether
ston call out at the yard-gate for one of his men—Reeves went, and I saw him take up the iron tyre of a cart-wheel, and knock the padlock off, which was on a chain on the gate leading into the road, and Mr. Fetherston came in—he then came round with a paper in his hand, went into the stable as if looking at the horses—he then came to the barn where I was, looked at the pigs, cows, and heifers, and I heard him say, "There is not sufficient to pay, we will have an entrance into the house"—all the prisoners were present except Sabin—they then went towards the house, and Reeves picked up a crowbar—I went into a cart-shed, right opposite the door, to see whether I could see, and when I got there they had forced an entrance into the house—I did not see them break in—I believe my master and mistress and the female servant were in the house—I have worked for Mr. Stephen Sabin twelve years, and have known him to have possession of this place twenty years, and he remained so till 7th May—I worked for his father—I do not know how young Sabin got in—the gate was locked then.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Young Sabin was not present when Fetherston said he should break in? A. No; I did not see him in the house.

Fetherston, Sen. Q. Do you recollect my calling on 27th April for rent? A. I saw you there, but do not know when it was, or what you said to my master—I do not remember master calling me while you were there—I never saw my master with a stick—I came to you and Gould one day with a knife in my hand, which I was eating my bread and cheese with—I do not remember Gould saying anything about a stick master had—I do not re
member that he had one; he might have; he often has a hoe—I did not hear Gould say, "My good man, be careful how you use that knife"—some
times

my master locks the gate, if he sees any persons about likely to get in—on 27th April he told me he locked the gate, because there were so many rough-looking men about, he thought they meant to come into his place, he did not know what they meant by coming down there, and said to me, "For the future you get over"—we unlocked the gate to get the horses out—my master did not say he expected the broker to come and seize for 150l. rent—I never heard him say Thomas Sabin was tried for the property—I have often heard him say it was freehold—I have not heard him say he paid no rent.

WILLIAM WALLIS . I work for Mr. Stephen Sabin—I have known him to be in possession of the property nine or ten years—I went on Tuesday morning, 7 th May, at six o'clock—the gate was locked, and I got over—I went into the stable—Reeves, Fetherston, jun., Gould, Toms, Tubby, and Pearson, then came, and Reeves took out this distress-warrant (produced)—I saw Sabin a few minutes after, coming towards the stable—Gould went out and met him—my master shortly afterwards came—Featherston, jun., Reeves, Gould, Tubby, and Pearson, remained there all day—about eight in the evening I went with my master to the stable—he took hold of young Fetherston's collar, told him he had no business there, and must go off the premises—one of them knocked master's hat off, and Tubby held up a stick—they surrounded young Fetherston, and drove master away—I left with my master—I said they were too strong for us to get them out—next morning I went to the stable at six, and found Tubby, Gould, Pearson, and Reeves, there—about half-past six I saw Fetherston and his son come into the yard—I saw Reeves take a crow bar towards the house, and heard blows on the door—the two Fetherstons and Gould were with him—they said before that that they intended to go round to the house, as there was not enough on the premises to pay—the crow-bar was about four feet and a half long, and as thick as my wrist—my master asked me if there was anything left in the stable—I found that paper hung up, and gave it him (produced.)
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you see young Sabin at the house? A. No.

Fetherston, Sen. Q. How did my men conduct themselves? A. Very well; they were civil and obliging to us—when I go before master is up I get over the gate; it is generally kept locked—I did not see the door broken open—it was Mr. Sabin's crow-bar—I afterwards saw the marks of the crow-bar—I did not see the gate broken open, I heard the blow—my master did not seize your son in a most ferocious manner, and shake him.

JANE HOLLINGE . I am servant to Mr. Stephen Sabin, the prosecutor; I know Thomas Sabin, and all the rest. On Tuesday night, 7th May, about eleven o'clock, I saw Thomas Sabin and the elder Fetherston at my master's gate, with a light, and heard one of them say they would be in the house in the morning—the next morning I saw Reeves break the lock of the gate—the two Fetherstons were waiting outside, and came in—Fetherston then came to the front door, which was locked, and demanded admittance—I was inside—he said unless the door was opened he would break it open in less than ten minutes—they then went round to the side-door, and broke it open with a crow-bar—I cannot tell who broke it open—the two Fether
stons, Reeves, Tubby, and Gould, then came in—an inner door, leading from the wash-house into the kitchen, was also broken with violence—I had fastened the doors the night before, and they had not been undone that morning—Fetherston ordered the men to open the front-door and the front-parlour shutters, which was done, and some of them went up-stairs—my mistress went into hysterics—my master was not at home.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Where did you see Fetberston and Sabin from on the Tuesday night? A. From the window, which it about twenty yards from the gate—there were more persons than them there, some inside and some out—it was a very dark night.

Fetherston, Sen. Q. Did your master give orders, on 8th May, that my son should remain in possession?A. Certainly not—I made a bed for him in the parlour; my mistress told me to do that—I did not hear my master say he preferred your son being left to any other man—your son was very poorly.

WILLIAM WILKINSON (policeman, R 235). I was on duty on 7th May, near the prosecutor's house, and at a little before eleven o'clock at night saw Fetherston, Thomas Sabin, and another, who I do not know, go up the yard-gate—Gould and Reeves, and some others, were inside—Fetherston said to those inside, "Well, how are you getting on here; have you got a comfortable place?"—Gould said, "No, very uncomfortable; but we will make ourselves comfortable for the night;" and Fetherston said, "We will have a better place for you to-morrow; we will have an entrance into the house"—Sabin was by at the time—Fetherston asked if they wanted anything to eat or drink for the night—they said, "No, that gentleman (pointing to Thomas Sabin) has let us have what we required for the night," and Sabin said, "I have"—Fetherston then said to me, "Policeman, I demand of you to see there is no breach of the peace here; my men won't do it."
Fetherston, Sen. Q. Did not I tell you I had a warrant? A. No, or that you had an execution on the premises—I was near the premises that night, to see there was no disturbance.

WILLIAM BELDHAM (police-constable, R 290). I was on duty that night, and saw some of the defendants—next morning, about six o'clock, I saw the two Fetherstons come to the gate, and try to get in—Fetberston said to Reeves, "Break the lock off"—Reeves picked up a piece of iron, and knocked the lock off—Fetherston afterwards went to the front-door, and said if they did not open the door, he would break every door in the house—they afterwards came back from the barn with a crow-bar, went to another door, and Reeves hammered away till they got in—all the defendants went in except Toms and Sabin.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you see Thomas Sabin at all that day? A. Yes, outside the premises.

p.hi: Fetherston, the elder, stated that he was employed to distrain for rent by Thomas Sabin, who produced a copy of the will, and satisfied him that he had a legal right to distrain.
Gould and Tubby stated they were employed by Fetherston.

div1.p: Fetherston, Sen., called STEPHEN SABIN. You asked me which of your men I wished to stay in possession—I did not give you any answer, and I am not aware that Mr. Turner did—you did not say to me, "If I leave my son in possession, will you treat him as one of the family."

—TURNER. I remember Fetherston entering the house on 8th May—Mr. Sabin did not, in my presence, consent to any man being left in possession—I remember your wishing to go up-stairs to take an inventory, and the ladies saying it was not convenient, and asked you to wait two or three minutes—you said you would wait not only two or three minutes, but three hours, and that you would not even go up at all; but when you first came in, you began to cut round us, and I did the same to you, and then you began to sing a little small—I did not see anything in your conduct except that of a gentleman.

THOMAS SABIN—
GUILTY:
HENRY FETHERSTON, SEN.,—

GUILTY .—
To enter into their own recognizances in 100l., and one security of 50l. each, to appear to receive judgment when called on, and to keep the peace until then.
FEATHERSTON, JUN., REEVES, GOULD, TUBBY, and PEARSON—
GUILTY .—
To enter into their own recognizances in 50l. each, to appear to receive judgment when called on, and to keep the peace till that time.

TOMS—
NOT GUILTY .

1201.
THOMAS BRYANT
, feloniously receiving 1 spirit-pump, value 14s.; the goods of
John Hammond, well knowing it to have been stolen.

JOHN HAMMOND . I keep the Star and Garter, Woolwich. A man named Brown was in the habit of using my house—I had a copper pump in my stable, worth 14s. or 15s.—I had not seen it for some time when Gladwin came, and in consequence of what he said I found it was not there—Brown was apprehended by my direction, and I went on 17th May with him and Gladwin to the prisoner's shop—Gladwin asked Bryant if he had brought any copper or pump—he said he had brought some copper—Gladwin asked how much—he said, "2lbs. or 31bs."—he produced this, and said, "That is it" (produced)—that has nothing to do with my pump—this metal is much thinner—my pump weighed 6lbs. or 7lbs., and had a sort of cylinder, or basin, at the top.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. What is Brown? A. He is a porter—the prisoner's book was produced—there was an entry corresponding with this copper, but the date did not correspond—he pointed out an entry referring to copper on the 13th—the weight to that was I think 3lbs.—there was no entry of copper on the 16th.

GEORGE BROWN (a prisoner.) On 16th May I took a copper pump of Mr. Hammond's, about three yards long, and broke it into three pieces—each piece remained a portion of a pump—I took it to Mrs. Ford—she refused to buy it, and I took it to the prisoner's, who is a marine-store dealer—I asked whether he would buy it—he said, "Yes"—he weighed it, and said it came to 15d.—I do not know what it weighed—he did not ask me any questions at all—I was half tipsy—he went out of his shed to his house, got the money, paid me, and I left—we had to go into the street to get to his house, leaving the copper in the shed.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A labouring man—I was employed that day to wash two carriages—I am not in constant employment—I live in High-street, Woolwich—I was applied to to be a witness since I have been here—I was not told it would be better for me—I hope I shall get off—this is the first time I have been charged with anything—I was not acquainted with Bryant—I have never been in Maidstone Gaol—the copper produced is not part of what I sold the prisoner.

MART FORD . I keep a marine-store shop, in Union-street, Woolwich. On 16th May, Brown brought a big round piece of copper, like a spout—he was tipsy, and I refused to have anything to do with it—I saw him go to Bryant's shop, and come out again with him—he then had no parcel—they went to Bryant's dwelling-house, and then Brown went away—he had nothing with him then.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been a marine-store dealer? A. Between five and six years—I live next door but one to Bryant—I am on good terms with him—I have lived in the same house twenty-seven years—I never kept a brothel—I kept a lodging-house—the parties lodged there a night, and away again—I give 5d. for old copper.

MARTHA BORER . I am the last witness's daughter. I recollect Brown coming on 16th May—he had a parcel, which mother said she would not have, and he went with it to Bryant's shed—I saw him come out of there again with nothing—he passed quite close to me, and I heard Bryant say, "Did I say fourteen, or fifteen?"—Brown said, "Fifteen"—they went into Bryant's house, and came out again—Bryant went to his shed, and Brown up Star-and-garter-alley.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Bryant very well? A. Yes; my brother-in-law assists him in his business—I do not know whether he assists him in keeping his books—I know Mrs. Taylor, who also assists him—marine-store dealers generally keep a book, and enter what they buy.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman, G 122). I apprehended Brown on the 17th May—we went to Bryant's shop, and I asked Brown to point out the man—he pointed out Bryant, and I asked him where the spirit-pump was—he said, "I bought no spirit-pump"—I said, "Copper"—he said he only bought two pounds—I asked to see his book—he showed it me, and I left it in his possession—he showed me this copper, and said that was it—Brown said, "It was in three pieces, and you gave me 15d. for it"—Bryant said, no, he did not, and stooped down, pointing to Mrs. Taylor, his housekeeper.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he say anything about Mrs. Taylor? A. No; he signified by pointing that she paid the money—the Magistrate admitted him to bail, and he surrendered here to-day.

GUILTY .** Aged 49.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1202.
JOHN BURLEIGH,
WILLIAM BRYAN,
JOHN OBIE,
MARY ANN STONE , and
EMMA SMITH
, stealing 1 purse, and 1 knife, value 1s., 1 half-crown, 1d., and 1 1/2d.; the property of
Mary Ann Stevens, from her person: Burleigh having been before convicted: to which

BURLEIGH pleaded—
GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Confined Twelve Months.

JOHN CARPENTER (policeman, R 38). On 22nd May I was on duty in Deptford, between five and six o'clock, and saw the prisoners together, I did not know them before; I watched them into a crowd; they went to a lady, the little boy Burleigh stood at her side, Bryan and Obie behind her, and the females in front; Burleigh felt her pocket, and then they all went to another part—they went to several persons, and then to Mrs. Stevens—Stone pushed Burleigh near Mrs. Stevens, Bryant and Obie placed themselves near Bur
leigh, looking down upon him to see what he was doing—Smith placed herself so as to hide him. Burleigh got his hand in Mrs. Stevens's pocket and took it out with nothing in it—Stone looked, and seeing he had not got any thing, stopped till Burleigh put his hand in again, and it came out with a purse in it—I was down on my knees, and got up as they were all going out of the crowd, and with assistance took them all in charge—Burleigh threw down a purse; he had his left-hand in his coat pocket—I put my hand in, pulled his out, and took from it a half-crown, one penny, and one halfpenny—they all resisted very much, and denied all knowledge of each other, except Bryant and Obie, who said they came together.

MARY ANN STEVENS . I am a widow. On 27th May, I went to Dept
ford fair—I had a half-crown, one penny, and one halfpenny in my pocket; a purse with nothing in it, and a knife—I saw Burleigh look up in my face—the officer spoke to me; I missed my purse, and saw it in his hand; my money was all gone but a halfpenny—this is my purse and knife—(produced.)

JAMES WILLIAM CROUCH (policeman R 0 361). I saw all the prisoners toge
ther
in the fair—Obie had his left arm on Stone's shoulder, in conversation—I saw Burleigh take something from Mrs. Stevens's pocket—they were then all of a row round her—I took Bryant and Obie.

BRYANT—
GUILTY .** Aged 16.

OBIE—
GUILTY .** Aged 18.

STONE—
GUILTY .** Aged 18.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1203.
JOHN KIMBER
, feloniously uttering a forged order for the pay
ment of 3l., with intent to defraud
Benjamin Hayden: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 61.—
Confined Nine Months.

1204.
JANE BUTLER
(indicted with
Mary Ann Gillingham, tried last Session; see page 117,) stealing one purse; and 1 medal, value 7d.; 3 pieces of silver coin, value 6d.; 50 sovereigns, 4 sixpences, and I 10l. Bank-note; the property of
Samuel Buckmaster, her master, in his dwelling-house: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined One Year.

1205.
OCTAVIUS RYLAND
for feloniously sending to
William Bengo Collyer a certain letter, demanding money from him, with menaces, and without any reasonable or probable cause: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Transported for Life.

1206.
GEORGE WEST
, stealing 2 pairs of reins, value 1l.; the goods of
Sir David Baird, Bart.:
also, 1 coat, 1 pair of boots, 1 pair of trowsers, and 1 jacket, value 21s.; the goods of
Edwin Mabbett: to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Six Months.

1207.
ELLEN ROYAL and
CATHERINE ROACH
, feloniously break
ing and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Hodges, and stealing one loaf of bread, 10 cabbages, 2 ozs. weight of coffee, and 2 1/2 lb. weight of sugar, value 9d.; his property.

HENRY HODGES . I am an umbrella-maker, and live at 1, Webb's-place, Union-street, Southwark. On Sunday, 11th May, about 10 minutes past six o'clock, I heard a noise, got up and opened my window, and saw Royal standing outside the window in the court with a young man—I asked what they wanted, and at that moment Roach stepped out of the parlour window into the court—I had bolted that window when I went to bed, about half-past eleven the night before, and the shutters were bolted—I slipped on my trowsers, ran down-stairs, and followed them—the young man dropped a loaf at the top of the court—I did not meet a policeman till I got into Mint-street; I then gave Royal into custody—they had all three gone away toge
ther—I am certain the prisoners are the parties, for they looked up at me when I was at the window—the loaf was mine, and I also missed the other things stated—they had been just inside the window.

JOHN DELANY (policeman, M 18). I took Royal on 12th May—she was remanded, to give an opportunity of getting the other prisoner, but in conse
quence of not being able to get her, Royal was discharged, and the Magistrate ordered her to be re-apprehended when Roach was taken—On 21 st May I

took Roach, took her before the Magistrate, and then by his order I reappre
hended Royal—she said she had none of the things, and Roach also denied it.

ROYAL—
GUILTY * Aged 20.

ROACH—
GUILTY .* Aged 19.

1208.
JAMES M'NAIR
, stealing 25 cigars and 4 oz. weight of tobacco, value 4s. 2d.; 8 half-crowns, 60 pence, and 120 halfpence; the property of
John Hippisley, in his dwelling-house, and afterwards burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house.

ROBERT RATLEY . I was formerly in the V. division of police. About three o'clock in the morning of 18th April, I was on duty in Southampton-street, Lambeth, and heard some one walking in the yard at the back of the Southampton Arms public-house—I pulled myself up to the top of a side gate, looked over, and saw the prisoner coming down the stone-steps leading from the house into the yard—I could see him plainly; I have no doubt about him—I have known him for years, he is the son of the person who used to keep the house—I got down from the gate and went back for three or four yards, and he came and put his hands on the top of the gate, and his feet on the top of the bar, and got up—I asked what he did there—he said he was waiting for some Norman cows that were coming up by the railroad—I told him he had no business there, and he instantly went back—I went and spoke to Howard, another constable, and in two or three minutes I went in by ano
ther gate, leaving Howard there—I found the door at the top of the steps where I had seen the prisoner, wide open—I went in and called up the land
lord, and we searched the place all over, but could not find the prisoner.

Prisoner. Q. You say you saw me quite plain? A. Yes, I was about three yards from you—I have known you three or four years, and am certain you are the man—I should know you from a thousand—I did not see you that night at the corner of Nine-Elms-lane, nor did you then tell me about the cows.

JOHN HIPPISLEY . I keep the Southampton Arms, Lambeth; I have had the house twelve months; I succeeded the prisoner's father when he left the house. On 18th April, about three o'clock in the morning, I was called up by the policeman, and found the front and back-doors open—(I had gone to bed about half-past eleven overnight, and left all the doors bolted)—I missed two papers containing copper money, eight half-crowns, and some cigars and tobacco—I had left them in a drawer—I know the prisoner quite well—I saw him in our house about seven o'clock the previous evening, the 17th—I have here a paper similar to that in which the tobacco I lost was wrapped.

DAVID PEGRAM (policeman, L 161). On the night of 18th April the prisoner was brought to the station on a stretcher, from the effects of swal
lowing a screw of tobacco—he was brought in for dead, insensible—I sent for a medical man, who recovered him, and he was taken home—after he was gone, in consequence of information, I went after him, and found him at 55, Mount-street, Westminster-road, a night-house—I told him I had received information from the B division station that he was wanted, for a robbery at the Southampton Arms—he made use of some words to his companion, which I could not understand, owing to the noise in the house—I searched the pri
soner, and found on him two half-crowns, two sixpences, 5 1/2d. in copper, two screws of tobacco, and one paper which had had tobacco in—I have also produced a paper which was given me by Mr. Hippisley, and three others which I got as samples from the prosecutor's house.

JOHN HIPPISLEY
re-examined. This is the paper I gave the policeman—it was cut from a memorandum-book, and the papers left behind in the drawer correspond in the figures and writing with those found on the prisoner—I do not make up the screws myself; we buy them ready made up—I sold some of these the same morning—I had in two pounds of them the same evening, at seven o'clock.

JOHN CROUCH . I am clerk to a gentleman, and live at 9, Bond-street, Vauxhall. On Wednesday, 17th April, I was at the bar of the Southampton Arms, between eleven and twelve o'clock, and saw the prisoner come in—I knew him before—I left as near twelve o'clock as possible, and I believe I left him there.

JAKES SKUDDER . I am potman to Mr. Hippisley. On the night of 17th April I shut up the shutters, about twenty-five minutes to twelve o'clock—there was then only one person in the room, and that was a porter—I saw the prisoner sitting outside the front-door on a seat—I am sure it was him—I spoke to him—I had seen him in the tap-room, between eleven and twelve—I bolted the back-door before I went to bed, about five minutes past twe e—my mistress and the servant were the last persons up—they are not here—a gentleman who was in the tap-room that night said that he expected some Alderney cows up next morning, and the prisoner was there at the time.

ANN SIMPSON . I am single, and live at 2, Vale-place, Duke-street, West
minster-road. On the morning of 18th April, I met the prisoner at Hart's public-house, in Mount-street—we had something to drink, and he went home with me—he gave me half-a-crown and sixpence, and he also gave me a cigar or a cheroot—he had given one to some females at the public-house—he paid 1s. 11 1/2d. for his breakfast—he had about half-a-dozen cigars in his hand—I saw no papers of tobacco.

HENRY HART . I am barman to my father, who keeps the New Crown and Cushion, in Westminster-road. On 18th April, between four and five in the morning, the prisoner came and had half-a-pint of gin, which I believe he paid for in silver—he then asked if I would oblige him by giving him five shillings for a five shilling packet of halfpence, but I said I did not want them—he then broke open a package of halfpence, and spent three or four shillings' worth treating a lot of persons at the bar, and he smoked some cheroots or cigars which he took out of his pocket—he left the house a little after six with Simpson—I did not hear of his swallowing any tobacco.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of it.
(The prisoner received a good character)

p.rs: GUILTY of Stealing in the dwelling-house. Aged 22.—Recommended to mercy

p.hi:
by the Jury.—
Confined One Year.

div1.p:
1209.
JAMES HICKEY
, feloniously assaulting
Henry De Coster, with intent to rob him.

HENRY DE COSTER . I am a tailor, and live at 28, Great Union-street, Southwark. On Monday morning, 20th May, between one and two, I was going home—a female was with me, not my wife—the prisoner came up, and asked me for money—I had no small change, and I went into a public-house to get change, and gave him 2d.—he then asked me to give him some beer—I gave him a pint of porter, and left the house, and I was surprised to find myself quickly followed by the prisoner, who demanded more money of me, saying that he wanted to pay for his lodging, and it would come to 6d.—he said he had just come into town off the road, and he was very tired, and had

no other means—I told him I could not give him any more, I was but a working man myself, and I had nothing else but two half-crowns in my pocket—I told him to go about his business, or I would give him in charge—he still followed me from the Obelisk in Black friars'-road all the way round Union-street, till I got opposite my own door, when he attacked me, and struck me—I struggled with him, and called for the police, who came to my assistance, or no doubt I should have been robbed—I found my watch hanging from my pocket by the guard-chain—I was perfectly sober.

Cross-examined by MR. WOOLLETT. Q. Where had you been? A. To see a friend part of the way home, it being late—it was a female friend who had been spending the evening at my house—she resided somewhere in the Waterloo-road, I do not know where—I had left her and was returning home—I called the female who was walking with me Mrs. De Coster—I did not say she was my wife—I will not swear 1 did not—that was not the same lady I had been to see home, but another—the prisoner was sober—I could not see a constable all the way he followed me, or I should have given him in charge—I did not meet any person—I did not strike him—I laid hold of him when he laid hold of me, or I should have fallen—the female cried out for police—after he got to the station he threatened to do for me after he got his liberty.

EDWARD FISHER (policeman, M 272). In consequence of hearing a cry I went into Great Union-street, and found the prisoner and prosecutor there—the prosecutor gave him in charge for assaulting him, and demanding money of him—I took him to the station—he said to the prosecutor, "I know where you live, and I will mark you when I come out."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

1210.
WILLIAM GROVES
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Linfield, with intent to steal.

ELIZABETH SARAH LINFIELD . I am the wife of James Linfield, a grocer and broom-dealer, at 54, Tiverton-street, Newington. On Wednesday morning, 22nd May, I was awoke, about a quarter or twenty minutes past three o'clock, by the noise of the shop shutters breaking—I looked out of the bedroom window and saw a hat go in at the shop window—I got a light, and in about five minutes went down-stairs into the shop—I found the window and shutters open, which I had left safe about eleven over night, and saw the prisoner lying down behind the counter—I said, "Man, what do you do here?"—he made no answer, and never moved—he was very tipsy indeed—I called my husband, who got a policeman, and gave him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. BIRNIE. Q. Did you miss anything? A. No; I had 30s. in the till—not a thing was disturbed—I put my foot against him when I asked what he did there—he was led to the station by my husband and a policeman—he seemed to have no legs to walk upon—I had never seen him before—the shutters were very old and rotten, the least touch might have broken them.
THOMAS GRANVILLE (policeman, M 251). I was called, and received the prisoner in charge—he was very tipsy—I could make nothing of him—he was not able to walk very well.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

1211.
EDWIN SMITH
, stealing 9 bagatelle-balls, value 2l.; the goods of
Benjamin Moore; having been before convicted.

BENJAMIN MOORE . I keep the Rose and Thistle, in Londonderry-road, Walworth—I keep a bagatelle-table in my house. On 8th April several men came to my house, I cannot tell how many—I remember two men coming, about a quarter-past eight o'clock; they went into the parlour, where the bagatelle-table is, and staid about ten minutes—when they left I went in, and the lights were turned out—as soon as I lighted them I found the nine bagatelle-balls were gone—they were worth about 2l.—I am not able to identify either of the men—one had left a basket with Mrs. Moore in the bar, and he took it from her when they came out—I saw the man leave it—I cannot swear to his features, I did not see his face.

Prisoner. Q. I think you stated that you a had a subscription skittle-ground? A. I have—there were three or four persons playing in that ground that evening—mine is a spirit-house, a general house of business—this was on a Monday—my attention was called to that day by' my having paid my brewer—I went out after the loss to give information at the station-house—I saw the policeman Grant next day—I usually attend to the persons who play at skittles—1 attended to the bar that evening—I was not sitting in my parlour at the back of my bar, when the two men came in; I was standing in the bar, in a corner that projects into the passage—my parlour-door is down the passage—I could not have seen that parlour if I had been in my back-parlour—after the first examination, the policeman Grant called on me; the next day, I believe; he has frequently been to me—I have not treated him, he always paid for what he had—I did not undertake to describe you at the police-station, no furthar than your hat; it was a peculiar hat—I was present when my servant gave a description of the person to the police—I heard her describe you—I was in the bar, and saw two men—I will not swear to your having been in the house.
MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. What hat had he on? A. One of those Paris hats, with no beaver on it, or that shuts up—I will not swear that it did shut up.

JANE ELIZABETH PEARSON . I am servant to Mr. Moore. On the night of 8th April I saw the prisoner at my master's house; I saw him when he was going out; he came from the parlour where the bagatelle-table is, along to the bar—he asked Mrs. Moore for a basket he had left, and she gave it shim—I am sure the prisoner is the man—there was a person came out of the parlour at the time the prisoner did; 1 do not know that he was with him—it was twenty-five minutes past eight o'clock.

Prisoner. Q. Where were you standing? A. At the bar—my master was inside the bar—it was a long flag basket, a sort of tool-basket—when I first saw you at the station I had not a doubt of your being the person from the alteration of the dress—the man had on a light plaid coat, with dark stripes—when the policeman came to fetch me I did not have any conversation with him and Mr. Moore; I was behind them—I do not recollect that I heard any conversation with them—my master has a subscription skittle-ground; he generally attends to it—there were two or three persons there—those who left the parlour went in the skittle-ground—I attend to the parlour sometimes—I took a pot of porter to those men at eight o'clock—a few minutes after I took the beer in, the men came out, and went to play—I did not see any

strange man in the parlour; there were none but what I knew—the man who took the basket came from the passage from the direction of the parlour—I do not know what that man had had—you were not in the parlour when I took in the beer—there was not much playing in the bagatelle-room after twenty-five minutes past eight that evening—I remember the first examina
tion at the police-court—I cannot tell who described you to Mrs. Moore on our return home—I dare say there was some conversation; I cannot recollect what it was—I did not describe you to Mrs. Moore—I do not know that Mr. Moore did—I do not recollect how soon afterwards I saw the policeman Grant—he did not advise how I should give evidence—I cannot tell whether Mr. and Mrs. Moore were present when I gave a description of the man to the policeman—I gave a description before the policeman came—I do not know that Mr. Moore asked me the description before he went to the station—we were all in a muddle—the last person I saw come from the parlour to the bar was the person who took the basket—there were two men came out—I will not swear whether any one else went into the parlour at that time—I do not know whether the skittle-ground was searched by Mr. Moore—he was not there when the men came out of the parlour, he was in the bar—I described one person to the policeman, in the hearing of Mr. and Mrs. Moore—I was here last Session—Grant did not say to me, "Mind you swear as you did before, or you will get yourself in a mess"—there was no witness near me and Grant, who overheard that—Grant did not say, "There is a witness for Smith; let us go further"—it was my master who first discovered the loss.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Did you hear the prisoner apply last Session to have the case postponed till this Session because be had no witnesses here? A. Yes; I had no conversation of the kind the prisoner has mentioned—when I saw him I knew him again instantly—I recognized him of my own accord—I have no doubt at all he is the man—as soon as the loss was discovered I gave a description of the man who had come out for the basket—when I saw him at the station he was dressed differently, but in spite of that I recognized him by his features—I said, "You are the man, although you have got a different coat on"—he said, "I don't know where your house is"—the prisoner was not in the parlour when I took the pot of beer in—it was for a young man who is a customer—I did not see the prisoner go in, but I saw him come out.

COURT. Q. You know those persons that were in the parlour when you went in; did you see what they were doing? A. They were playing at bagatelle—the man who called for the basket, came from the passage that leads to the parlour, right past the bar—there is no other way of getting to the passage than coming from the parlour.

MARGARET MOORE . I am the wife of Benjamin Moore. I was in the bar on the evening of 8th April; I saw the prisoner there soon after eight o'ctock—he came straight into the house, and a young man with him—he brought a basket with him, and asked me to take charge of it—he went into the parlour with the young man—I saw the door shut after they went into the parlour—I had heard the bagatelle balls about five minutes before that—the lights were then burning, and as the prisoner went into the parlour, I saw the lights there—no other person went into the parlour or came out after the prisoner went in—the prisoner and the young man did not call for any refreshment—they came out in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—the prisoner asked for the basket—the young man did not speak—I said to the prisoner, "I suppose these are flower-roots in the basket"—he said, "No, they are rhubarb

roots"—my husband was in the bar at the time—I went to the parlour some time after—I found the gas was out, and the balls were gone—no other per
sons had gone into the parlour but those persons—soon afterwards some persons came and wished to go in, but the lights were out, and the balls were gone.

Prisoner. Q. You were not sitting in the bar-parlour when the man came in? A. No; I was standingin the bar—my husband generally attends to the skittle-ground, but he was in the bar when the men came in—I do not know whether he saw you, he might have been engaged—I saw the man, he had a plaid coat on, rather short—I and the servant described the man to the police the next morning—I saw the policeman, Grant, on the morning after the examination—I had not seen you then at the police-station—the policeman asked how you were dressed, and whether you had a light complexion; and as far as I remembered I told him—I saw Mrs. Graham at the police-station; I had some conversation with her; I did not describe you to her—when Grant came to oar house there was not a general conversation in order to learn how the evidence should be given—he did not say, "Stick to that evidence"—he was not treated by me—what my husband did I cannot say—the basket was a long basket, such as carpenters would carry—I should think there were about six persons in the parlour when the pot of beer was ordered—some of them left to go to the skittle-ground—my husband attends to that ground, but he was in the bar; I do not know whether he was serving—he did not leave to go to attend the men in the skittle-ground—it was not subscription-night—the two men came in together, one carrying the basket—the one that left the basket bad a check coat on—I swear that was you—we have only one parlour—I was in the bar the whole evening—I can swear those men came from the parlour—I am sure they did not come from the skittle-ground.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Who is Mrs. Graham? A. The wife of Mr. Graham, who lost some balls—that is another charge against the prisoner—when I went to identify the prisoner, there were two others called with him—they asked me, "Do you know either of these persons?"—I said, "Yes," and pointed the prisoner out.

JAMES GRANT (police-sergeant, P 11). From information, I took the prisoner into custody—I charged him with stealing the bagatelle-balls from Mr. Moore's—he said he did not, he did not know where the house was, and he had never been in the house.

Prisoner. Q. From whom did you receive the information of the robbery? A. At the station—I went to Mr. Moore's house—Mrs. Moore and the servant gave me a description of you—I had seen you repeatedly before—I knew where you lived—I made some inquiries—there were certain reasons for my not going to the house—I was not certain that you were living there—I knew you went there occasionally, and you were to be found there at different times—I saw you before you went to the house, and followed you into the house—you gave me the address in South-street—the address was in your pocket—I have never seen you in company with thieves, you were generally alone when I saw you—as soon as they gave me the description, I said I believed I knew the person—the servant came to the station, and identified you at once; and Mrs. Moore, as soon as ever she saw you with three or four others, pointed you out—two persons were described to me, but you were the most likely person—I did not find a basket or any check coat at your lodgings—I have been to Mr. Moore's several times since that—I had some conversation with them—I was not treated—I paid for what I had.
MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Did the description given you by Mrs. Moore and her servant answer the description of the prisoner? A. Yes.

Prisoner. Q. You had no difficulty in finding me? A. I looked for you, but I was not watching the house night and day—I had some difficulty in finding you out, or I should have taken you before—you were in the habit of going out at all hours—I have not seen you late at night, but I have heard that you came in very early in the morning—I did not see you after the robbery—you were pointed out to me by a constable in the Walworth-road, about nine months ago, as a convicted thief, and since then I have frequently seen you; and as soon as I received this information, I looked for you—I had seen you at No. 5, George-street. Walworth-common—I knew afterwards that you did not live there, but I did not know at the time—I made inquiries from 9th April till the 22nd, and looked for you as well—I took you on the 22nd.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. You say he was pointed out? A. Yes, as a convicted thief—I kept my eye on him, and if I saw any constable, I pointed him out to him—after I had received this information, I looked out for him, and took him the first time I saw him.
MRS. MOORE re-examined. I saw the person who left the basket go into the parlour, and another person with him—at that time there was no other person in the parlour.
