Prisoner's Defence. It is a circumstance of identity; after the witnesses I shall call, you will satisfy your mind that I am not the person who is guilty: I do not know the house.

ANN MURRAY . I have known the prisoner a year and a half—I do not remember 8th April—he was given into custody on the 22nd—he never wore any other coat but the one he has on, except a black one—I had never seen any acquaintance of his coming to my place, wearing a check-coat—I cannot tell what time he was home on 8th April—he never had a check-coat on—I saw that he possessed a carpenter's basket—when he was given into custody, I was surprised at my place being searched—I take in washing—he might have taken things in my place if he had been disposed.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. You have known him a year and a-half? A. Yes, and his wife nearly two years—he had an opportunity to take things from me—I do not come here to give him a character—I know he has been convicted—he was in prison when Mrs. Smith came to my house—he lodges at my house—I do not know what he does—since he has been at my place he has never done work—he is something of a carpenter or a cabinet-maker—I do not know where he works—I have been in his room, it is always open—he has gone out at eight or nine o'clock in the morning—he has come home at ten or eleven at night—he sleeps at the top of the house.

WILLIAM GREEN . I did live at No. 5, George-street. On 8th April the prisoner came in, between five and six o'clock in the evening—he stopped there till after the public-houses were shut up between twelve and one; he played a number of games of cribbage with me and Barker—he did not pay his reckoning, because the beer-house was shut up.

Cross-examined. Q. Barker was playing. A. Yes; I am a coster-monger—I get my living by selling fish and other things in the street—I sold fish the week before last, all that week, round Peckham. I have a two-wheeled barrow—I had only one day's work last week—that was on Saturday, selling gooseberries and rhubarb—I cannot tell what I was doing last Tuesday fort
night—I was not asked to come here as a witness, I was subpoenaed—here is my subpoena—this was the first intimation that I had that I was to be called as a witness—nobody had been talking with me about what we had been

doing that evening till I got this subpoena—some young man brought it this morning—on 6th April I was up in the Walworth-road selling rhubarb, and cabbages, and greens; Barker was with me—I think that day I dined at Edward Smith's, who lives up a turning in South-street—I then lived at 5, George-street—I now live at my mother's—I had seen the prisoner before the night of 8th April, and spoken to him—he did not live in that house—Barker now lives along with me at my mother's in Waterloo-street—he did lodge with me in George-street—on the night we were playing cribbage there was me and Barker, the prisoner, Edward Smith and his wife—no one but us five—I had been with Barker all day—we had been to market, and could not buy anything—we came and staid at home, and in the evening we played at cribbage—Barker played first, and then I did—it was two-handed cribbage—we only played for beer—a pint of beer a game—we had two pots of beer brought in—Edward Smith brought them both in—Edward Smith did not play—he did not bet—Mrs. Smith did not play—I think I played three games—I won them all—I think the prisoner played more games with Barker, but I eannot say how many, for I was out a little while—I went out between eight and nine, that was before I played—I had seen Barker play, but I cannot tell how many games—I was in again in half an hour's time—Barker did not play after I played—we played and talked between the games—we had a cribbage-board—I cannot tell how long it took to play the three or four games—I have never been in trouble, nor before a Magistrate—I do not know John George Sharpe, nor Harriet Rathbone—I have heard Mr. Smith talk about them—I never saw them.

WILLIAM BARKER . I remember playing cribbage on Monday, 8th April, a fortnight before the prisoner was taken—in consequence of our not having money to buy anything we stopped at home and smoked our pipes, and drank tome beer—I played first, and then Green played three or four games, and then I played again—the prisoner came between five and six o'clock, and left between one and two in the morning.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A hawker—I hawk all manner of things, fruit and fish—I live with Green, in Waterloo-street—I hawked yesterday—Green did not hawk with me, but he was out selling cocoa
nuts—the day before yesterday he was round with his barrow in his usual business—he works every day—I know all about him—he was not out all the week because he could not buy anything, but he was out on Saturday with goose
berries and rhubarb—I should say he took 11s. or 12s.; he earns something every day when he is out—I hardly remember where I was on 6th April, I think I was out—the first time I was asked to come here was on Saturday last—Mrs. Smith asked me to come and speak what I knew of the day he was playing cards with me—she asked me what day that was, and I told her—Green did not go out at all during the time we were playing—I am sure of that, as far as I can recollect—I believe I played first—I think Green was rather the luckiest—I think we had between two and three pots of beer—I think it was three—Mr. Smith that I lodge with fetched the beer—I think, on 4th April, I was out round the streets with my barrow selling fish—I have never been in trouble in my life.
Prisoner. Q. I think if you charge your memory you will find that Green went out? A. I do not remember it—I will swear positively that you did not leave the house till twelve o'clock at night.

JAMES GRANT
re-examined. The public-house is about a mile and a half from where I apprehended the prisoner—I know 5, George-street—that is about a mile and a half from Moore's.

GEORGE QUINNEAR (police-sergeant, P I). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, at Newington—(read—Convicted, July, 1848, by the name of Thomas Smith, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the person.
GUILTY .

1212.
EDWIN SMITH was again indicted
for stealing 9 bagatelle-balls, value 30s.; the goods of
Robert Graham.

ROBERT GRAHAM . I keep the Rose and Crown beer-house, in William-place, Walworth-road. On 2nd Feb. I had nine bagatelle-balls, and I lost them between a quarter-past nine and ten o'clock, as near as possible—I saw the prisoner that night at my house—he came up-stairs into the room, and requested to play bagatelle—I did not know him before—I am quite sure he is the person—he came with a person named White, who has been convicted—I knew White before—they played up-stairs, in the club-room—there was no other person there—I saw them leave both together, and I had my suspi
cions—I sent my wife up-stairs the next moment—she called out, and I went out after the men—I ran them down a street, and they escaped into the gardens—they ran, and got away—White was afterwards taken—I am quite sure the prisoner was one of the two.

Prisoner. Q. You say two persons came into your house? A. Yes; there were more persons down-stairs, but only two in the room up-stairs, you and your companion—I gave information to the police, and gave a description of the two parties—I went to Horsemonger-lane to prosecute White—I know Rawlings—my testimony and my wife's did not convict him and White—that was for another offence—Rawlings was not at my house on 2nd Feb.—I do not know your wife—she might have called at my house—since you have been taken on this case, no one has called to ask me to give them infor
mation respecting White and Rawlings—your father called on me one night—I did not swear that White and Rawlings were in my house—you were dressed in a check coat.

SOPHIA GRAHAM . I am the wife of Robert Graham. On 2nd Feb., about a quarter or half-past nine o'clock at night, two persons came into our house—I am quite sure the prisoner is one of them—they asked if any one was up-stairs—there was no one but my husband—they went up, and asked my husband for a pint of beer and two pipes—my husband left them in the room, playing at the bagatelle board, which he gave them—I suppose they had asked for it—I had seen it before, and it was quite safe—I afterwards saw the two men come down-stairs—my husband was not in the room some part of the time—when the men left he was in the bar—when they came down the other man paid for what they had had—the prisoner waited for him, and they went out together—after they had left, my husband told me to run up-stairs—I went up, and the balls were gone—I am quite sure the prisoner is the man.

Prisoner. Q. Were you a witness against White? A. Yes; Rawlings was tried with him—Rawlings was sentenced to four months, and White to twelve months—I and my husband were not the only witnesses—we did not swear that those two men were the only men in our room that night—we did not swear to Rawlings—White was the person that came in with you—Raw
lings was not convicted on our case, but on Mr. Gardener's case—White and Rawlings were convicted for Mr. Gardener's case.

JAMES GRANT (police-sergeant, P 11). I took the prisoner on 22nd of April—I told him he was charged with being concerned with another in steal
ing bagatelle balls from the Rose and Crown beer-shop, on 2nd Feb.—he said he did not know where the house was, and never was in it.

Prisoner's Defence. I have endeavoured to ascertain who this White is, to clear myself, and I was obliged to write to the Magistrate; word came to me that White and Rawlings bad been convicted on the same charge; I feel con
vinced that Quinnear and Grant have got up the case against me.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1213.
JOHN BAXTER
, stealing 1 brass tap, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
John Beard; having been before convicted.

DANIEL HALEY (policeman, M 181). On 24th May, I was on duty in Kent-street, at a little before three o'clock in the morning—I stopped the pri
soner coming out of Hunter-street, and asked what be had in his pockets—he said a pint pot which he found near the Borough-road—I searched his pocket, and found in it three brass taps—this is one—he said he bought them of a man in Blackfriars-road for a shilling—I took him to the station, and went to Mr. Beard's, and showed him this tap—it had been in the yard at the back of his house—I observed some footmarks—I took the prisoner's shoe, and put it into the marks, and it corresponded—I saw the impression before I put the shoe in it.
JOHN BEARD . I am a gas lighter—this tap is mine—I saw it safe in the water-butt in my yard on the night before, about nine o'clock, and missed it about four next morning.
Prisoner. I bought the three taps of a man in the Blackfriars-road.
WILLIAM WEAVERS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction at Newington—(read—Convicted March, 1850, and confined two months)—I was then a constable, and was present—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

1214.
JOHN WHITE,
HENRY PAULTON , and
GEORGE WIXCEY
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; and 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 1 farthing; the property of
Emily Amelia Hunt: Wixcey having been before convicted.

EMILY AMELIA HUNT . I am tingle; I live in Manner's-street, Black
friars-road. On 19th April, I went into a coffee-house in Waterloo-road, about two o'clock in the moruing—I had a cup of coffee—I sat down by the side of White—I had not known him before—in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour he got up and left the house—I missed my purse, and my pocket was cut—I had had in my purse a half-crown, a shilling, and a farthing—I had it safe when I went into the coffee-house, and paid for the coffee out of it—I spoke to the people of the coffee-house, and then went to the police—I have not got my money or purse since.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. What are you? A. I have been in service, but I have been very ill the last month or six weeks, and not able to go—I had been to the theatre, and had had a glass of ale—the theatre was over at twelve o'clock—we had a walk—I think it was a little before two when I got to the coffee-house—I was not there longer than half an hour—I had no conversation with White, nor he with me—there were a great many people there; I spoke to none of them—I was not asleep; I was half-dozing—my eyes were shut.

GEORGE SAMUEL DURRANT . I was in the coffee-shop where the protecutrix was—the three prisoners were there—Wixcey was sitting in a box on the other side—White changed places with a man, and sat close to the prosecutrix—Paulton was standing by the fire-place—while the prosecutrix was sitting by White, I saw him lift up her clothes—he said to Wixcey be wanted a chive,

and Wixcey gave him a knife—Whit then lifted up her clothes again, cut a hole in her pocket, and took a little bead purse out—he then got up and walked out—the other two prisoners walked after him—I went out after they left, and saw Wixcey standing about with his basket of oysters.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A potter; I had been to the theatre, and was too late to get in at home—I went to the coffee-house next door to the theatre—I had a cup of coffee—I went to sleep; I cannot say for how long—I went in about one o'clock—perhaps it was about two when I went to sleep—I slept till about four—White was not talking to the prose
cutrix; he sat by her—that was about a quarter before four—I was sitting right opposite—she was asleep—I did not say anything.
CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant, L 8). I went to Charles-street, Waterloo-road, and took White and Paulton in charge.
HENRY HOUOHAM (policeman, L 159.) I produce a certificate of Wixcey's conviction at Newington—read—(Convicted March, 1846, and confined twenty-one days)—he is the person.

WHITE—
GUILTY .† Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

PAULTON—
NOT GUILTY .

WIXCEY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1215.
ELLEN GRANT
, stealing 1 half-crown; he moneys of
Hugh Rowen, from his person: having been before convicted.

HUGH ROWEN . I am a mason's labourer. On 12th May, between five and six o'clock in the morning I went into a whiskey-shop in St. Jame's-place, Graham-lane—the prisoner was there—she asked me if I was not going to give her a glass—I said, "No"—she put her hand in my waistcoat-pocket, and took out a half-crown and two penny-pieces—I shook her hand; the half-crown fell, and another female picked it up—I gave the prisoner in charge.

CHARLES JACKSON LEWIS (policeman, M 76). I was sent for, and took the prisoner—I told her the charge—she said she knew nothing about it, and it was a b—y shame she should be taken when he was talking to another girl.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent; I had never seen the man before.

JOHN DELANY (police-sergeant, M 18). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction at Newington—read—(Convicted May, 1849, and con
fined three months)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1216.
SPENCER BENHAM
, stealing 1 shirt-collar, value 1s. 6d., and 1 sixpence; the property of
James Rogers, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Two Months.

1217.
HENRY FORD
, stealing 91 feet of pipe, and two metal taps, value 35s.; the goods of
John Stevens and another, his masters.

WILLIAM HENRY WILLIAMS . I am in the employ of John and James Stevens, in Bridge-road, Southwark. The prisoner was in their employ—he left rather better than twelve monthsago, directly after this happened—it was his duty to execute any orders he received, to take the materials and book them to the number that corresponded with the order—to take them from the warehouseman—he was to do any job that he was ordered to do—the account was sent in for this work—it was not paid.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. How long was he in the service? A. Two or three times; perhaps, twelve months altogether—he was a gas
fitter

—the orders are generally given to the warehouseman—I do not gene-rally go to see the work done; I go sometimes, if there is anything worth notice—a man named Rainer was in our employ, as a labourer—I believe when a labourer was out at work, if there was a material wanted, he came and fetched it—the foreman had the charge of hiring any labourer—when the men or the labourer bring back any goods, the warehouseman, Mr. Baker, takes them in—perhaps at that time we had thirty or forty men—the pri
soner left of his own accord—we seat a policeman after him—a reward has been offered for him for twelve months—I do not keep the books; I some
times take the money—I superintend the whole concern—I have seen the prisoner drunk.

JOSEPH BAKER . I am warehouseman in the employ of Messrs, Stevens; it is my duty to give out to the gas-fitters anything required for the job they are employed in. I recollect the prisoner being in their service—I gave him some tin pipe twelve months ago—he told me it was to do work at the British and Foreign School—about twenty-four feet of pipe was delivered to him on 20th and 21st Feb., 1849—I have not seen any of those articles since—I have seen a bill which refers to them—I did not hear any
body speak to him as to what had become of those goods, but I know he was sent back to point out where the goods were.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you keep a book? A. Yes; I have the charge of the warehouse, and enter everything that goes out and that comes back—I do not make mistakes—I have not had accounts constantly sent back with mistakes—I had one sent back from Mr. Morley's, in Wood-street, but it was not my error, but that of the person who measured the work—I am hardly ever absent when the men bring the work back—every inch of pipe that is brought back is put down—I have not frequently, when things have been brought back, omitted to put them down—these things were taken partly by Rainer, and partly by the prisoner—Rainer is here—they were never brought back—the men bring back what they do not use from various jobs, and they are taken off the bill—I have the bill here and the day-book—Mr. Williams receives money, and Mr. Stevens, and Mr. Scales—Mr. Scales is not here—this is the book in which I entered the things I supplied the prisoner with—here is the place where he asked me for materials to work at the British and Foreign School—it was on 20th Feb., 1849—that was the first day we supplied him with anything for that job—he had 12 ft. 5 in. of 18 in. pipe.

Cross-examined. Q. Here seems to be an erasure here; you make mis
takes in your books? A. No; this word double is written on an erasure—I cannot see an erasure where this 12 is—here is an erasure—the whole of this is on an erasure—these alterations were made afterwards.

COURT. Q. What else is entered beside the pipe? A. One 3/4 in. union, one 3/4 T, four screws, and other things—I heard the prisoner say at the Court that he got drunk and lost it—this paper is the writing of Mr. Taylor, our clerk—I do not see that there are any screws in it—the next article is half-inch union-pipe—here is twelve inches in one of these books, and twelve in the other—one of these is the Tuesday's-book, and while the clerk is posting one, I use the other—I do not copy from one book into the other—this is the Tuesday's book; things go from hence into the journal—Wednesday's work is put in this other book—I swear 1 delivered these things myself to the prisoner or his labourer; I will not swear to which—I cannot tell how much I delivered to the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .
(There was another indictment against the prisoner, on which no evidence Was offered.)

1218.
THOMAS WARD and
JOHN SKELTON
, stealing 4 bushels of oats, value 10s.; the goods of
John Edwards Bennett, their master; and
WILLIAM RAYMENT ,
for feloniously receiving the same.

JOHN EDWARDS BENNETT . I am a hay and corn salesman, at King's Arms Wharf, Belvedere-road, Lambeth—I contract to supply hay and corn to the Government—Ward has been in my employ for eight or ten years as carman, and Skelton from twelve to fifteen years—he was granary-man—it was the carman's duty to draw oats to the barracks—I have a very slight knowledge of Rayment—it was Skelton's duty, as granary-man, to load Ward's cart—Ward takes out, in the course of a day, twenty or thirty quar
ters—I was in the habit of supplying the Regent's-park Barracks—I sent there every morning twelve quarters of oats, in twenty-four sacks—Rayment has never bought corn of me—I was not on the 3rd April to supply him with a sack of oats—Skelton and Ward had no authority from me to supply him with a sack of oats that day—I had employed Romain and Garforth to watch my premises at six o'clock that morning.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON? Q. Were you ever in partnership? A. Yes; that has been terminated from two to three years—I never was a bankrupt—no trustees have been concerned for me or for the benefit of my creditors—I have fourteen or fifteen carmen besides Ward—I have no other regular granary-man but Skelton—there is a man employed occasionally, if an extra man is wanted—I send out about thirty-six quarters of oats in a day, and hay and straw—no man takes corn but Ward, except on particular occasions—he always takes the corn to the barracks.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Did you give this particular order to Ward that day? A. There was no particular order, because it was his regular duty—suppose another order was to be taken out the same day, it would not be his duty to take it at that time—it was his duty to go to the barracks, and no other man—if he had oats to take elsewhere the same day, it would not be his duty to take them together—he had the twenty-four sacks for the barracks, and I never allowed him to take any other—I do not pretend to speak to this sack or these oats—my foreman is not here.

WILLIAM ROMAIN (police-sergeant, L 38). On 27th May, I watched the prosecutor's premises, from six o'clock in the morning, till twenty minutes before eight—while I was watching, I saw Skelton lowering down sacks from the granary, and Ward had a cart receiving the sacks from the granary—Garforth was with me—I saw the cart loaded, and come out from the wharf about twenty minutes before eight—1 followed the cart—it stopped at a coffee-shop a short time—Ward went in, and left the cart outside—I watched it, and never lost sight of it—Ward came out, and the cart then went over Westmin
ster-bridge, up Parliament-street, up St. Martin's-lane, through St. Giles, and to Cheyne-mews, Bloorasbury—that is not the way to the Regent's-park Barracks—Rayment has a stable in Cheyne-mews—Ward was with the cart all the time—from the time it left the granary till it got to Rayment's, there was no sack put in it or taken out of it—when the cart got to Rayment's, it pulled up in front of the stable, and Rayment came out of the stable imme
diately—Ward did not knock or ring, the gates were wide open—Ward got on the load, and handed a sack from the load on to Rayment's shoulder—Rayment carried it up a ladder into the loft—I followed him up into the loft, leaving Garforth in charge of the cart and Ward—when I got into the loft, Rayment was turning round, and was about to shoot the oats into a bin—I said, "Halloo! what are you going to do with these?"—he said, "The

carman has asked me to leave them here"—I said, "You don't require to shoot them for that; bring them down again"—he brought them down, and I desired him to pitch them against the stable-door—I then asked Ward how many sacks be had in his cart—he said "Twenty-four"—I said, "Then you brought twenty-five from the wharf"—he said, "No, I did not"—he said "I know nothing about that sack," pointing to the sack that Rayment had just brought down—I said, "You must consider yourselves both in custody," and I took them both to St. Giles' station, leaving Garforth with the cart and the two horses—at the station I explained the charge to the inspector; and Rayment said, "That sack of oats did not belong to Mr. Bennett"—he said he met Ward in St. Giles' on his journey, and he asked him to leave the sack of oats as he went along—I told the inspector I was prepared to prove that was false—Rayment did not make any answer to that—I had not lost sight of the cart—nothing of that kind had taken place at St. Giles', or anywhere else—the sack had a mark on it; I have it here, and a sample of oats from the barracks, after I shot them, and a sample from the sack that Rayment had, and a sample from the bulk—I and Garforth took the oats to the barracks and shot them—there were twenty-four sacks.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. When you went up into the loft, where was Ward? A. Down-stairs with the cart—I followed Rayment through the stable, up the ladder into the loft—I had the conversation with Rayment up-stairs—Ward did not hear what I said to Rayment in the first place, but he heard the conversation afterwards—it was about twenty minutes before eight in the morning when they left the wharf—I had been watching from six—I and Garforth did not keep together all the way, but we never lost sight of the load—we were not more than from twelve to twenty yards from it at any time—I saw nothing of Skelton after Ward had started—I did not go into any shop—Garforth was with me the whole way—he never was more than a dozen yards from me—I did not make any note of what passed at the time, or since—I saw my depositions at the police-court, and I have seen them since at Mr. Bennett's office at Furnival's-inn—I did not go there to see them—I heard them read over there—they were read, to see whether they were correct—they had been taken down before at the police-court—they were read to me there—I was asked if they were correct—I signed them—what was read at Mr. Bennett's was merely a copy—they were read to me, to see if the copy was correct—I had not the depositions—they were quite correct—I did not ask to have them read—I have not seen them since, nor a copy of them—it was not for the purpose of refreshing my memory that they were read, I did not require it.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNEIL. Q. When you were before the Magi
strate you could not recollect what Rayment had said? A. Yes, I did; there is my statement of what I said—Garforth did not remind me of what the statement was—I did not turn to Garforth and ask him what Rayment had said—I had no conversation with Garforth about what Rayment had said—I only went once to Mr. Bennett's office—I was told by his brother that he was the solicitor, and if I were going that way, I should call in as I passed—I did not go by appointment—my beat is in various parts of Lambeth—I am at times a plain-clothes man—it was from five to seven days before the Sessions that I went to Mr. Bennett's—it was after I had been before the Magistrate the last time—the depositions were only once read over at Mr. Bennett's—Garforth went with me—he happened to be passing that way—we did not talk about it as we went along, to my knowledge—I will swear we did not—I never lost sight of the cart—I did not notice how many times it turned—I
took care to follow it close up—the sacks were lying down in the cart—one was not at all separated from the others—there was not one sack apart from the others.

THOMAS GARFORTH (policeman, L 151). On 27th May, about six o'clock in the morning, I was watching Mr. Bennett's premises with Romain—about seven I saw a cart under the granary-window—I saw a sack of oats being let down—when the cart was loaded J saw it leave the wharf, and I fol
lowed it with Romain from the time it left the wharf till it got to Cheyne-mews—I did not once lose sight of it—Ward was driving it—when it got to Cheyne-mews, it drove down and stopped opposite Rayment's stable—I saw Ward get on the cart, and hand a sack of oats on to Rayment's shoulder—I have no doubt there was a word or two passed between them, but not many words—Rayment took the sack into the stable, and Romain followed him in—I took charge of Ward and the cart—I said to Ward, "You must consider yourself in my custody, for stealing a sack of oats that is gone in the stable"—he said, "Steal them, eh! I was ordered to deliver them here by my employer"—the sack of oats was brought down shortly by Rayment, and Romain followed him down—I eventually took care of the cart, and Ward and Rayment were taken by Romain—I and Romain went with the cart afterwards to the barracks, and Romain took a sample of the oats—I after
wards went to the Belvedere Wharf, and saw Skelton—the foreman asked him, in my presence, how many oats he had put on Ward's cart that morning—he said, "Twelve quarters, I think," and after hesitating a little he said, "After I had given him twelve quarters, as I thought, he said he had not enough by one sack, and I took a sack and filled it and gave it him"—I then asked him whether they used sacks with different names on them—he said, "Yes, we do use odd sacks sometimes"—I said, "Did you have a sack with the name of Anderson on it?"—he said, "We had a sack with that name"—I then took him into custody—I kept sight of the cart all the time—I did not see Rayment in St. Giles's, or anywhere else, put a sack of oats on the cart.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Have you refreshed your memory at all by your depositions, since they were taken? A. No; I wrote down a part of the deposition, a few words that Skelton made use of in the loft—I wrote it down, because I had so many things to think of—I often do make a memorandum—Romain is similarly employed—I do not know whether he made a copy of anything—I have not seen the depositions, nor heard them read over—nor copies of them from the time they were made—yes, I beg pardon, they were read over in my presence at Mr. Bennett's; I had forgotten that for the moment—I have not got the bit of paper here that I wrote: I left it at home—I keep a memorandum of all cases that I have—I look at it before I come out.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. How came you at Mr. Bennett's? A. I went with Romain—he said he was going over there, and I might as well take a walk with him—it was at the Southwark Police-court that he said that—I think it was last Friday; I will not be certain—I went before the Grand Jury yesterday—when I got to Rayment's it was about eight o'clock, or it might be ten minutes past—I did not have anything in going along—previous to the cart coming out of the yard we went and had a pint of beer—in going along with the prisoners they wished to have something—I was in the cab with them, and Romain came and asked if I would take anything—I said, "You may bring me a glass of stout," and he brought me one—I was with Romain when he was being examined—I do not recollect that he spoke to me while lie was being examined—I believe there was a mistake in

the clerk putting down a name—when he was asked what Rayment had said, he said what Ward said—I did not call his attention to it; Mr. Bennett did—he looked at me; but as they will not allow policemen to speak together he did not say anything.
MR. BENNETT re-examined. These oats are just the same as I am sending to the barracks—I have not the slightest doubt that they are the same—they are worth 10s. a sack when delivered.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Are they Russian oats? A. I do not know what to call them—they are good oats—they are worth 16s. or 16s. 6d. a quarter, but then there are expenses—I shall give them no other name than good oats.

(The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate were read as follows:—Ward says, "The sack of oats brought here was not the sack taken off my cart"—Skelton says, "I know nothing about his having twenty-five sacks that morning, and I did not say that Anderson's sack went away that morning; I said that a sack with the name of Duncan went away"—Rayment says, "The sack of oats did not belong to Mr. Bennett at all.")
(Ward and Rayment received good characters).

WARD—
GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and

Jury.—
Confined Three Months. RAYMENT—
GUILTY . Aged 61.—

p.hi: Recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p:
SKELTON—
NOT GUILTY .

1219.
JOSEPH HUDSON
, stealing 2 bottles, and 1 1/2 pint of oil, value 2s.; the goods of
Magnus Morton Hicks and another, his masters: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Two Months.

1220.
WILLIAM MOSS
, stealing 1 wooden keg, value 6d., and 28 lbs. weight of lead, 8s.; the goods of
Thomas Brandram and others, his masters.

CHARLES WILLIAM WITTED . I am in the employ of Messrs. Brandram and others, as foreman to the colour-works—they have a white-lead manu
factory at Rotherhithe—I have been in their employ thirteen years—the prisoner has been in their employ nearly nine years. On 5th Feb. he was loading his van under the crane at the mill-room door—he stood there to take his turn, and was loaded—he might have waited there ten minutes—near to where his van was there was behind the door a pile of twenty kegs of white lead placed one on the other in four rows, of five in each—they were of a particular size and quality, and a particular mark on them—I know what the prisoner had to take; it was four casks of 12cwt each, and two from 4cwt. to 4 1/2 cwt.—the small kegs were gallon kegs—this is one from the pile—after the prisoner had got the six casks that I saw loaded I had a com
munication from Murphy, and during the temporary absence of the prisoner I got into the van—I saw a slight aperture under the tarpauling—I opened it and I saw this keg there—I got down, and went to the place where the twenty kegs had been, and found only nineteen kegs, and each contained 28lbs. of superior quality—the prisoner was not to take any of this kind—he returned, and went on his journey to deliver his goods—I went to the superintendent, communicated what I had seen, and we followed the van together—the prisoner proceeded into the Deptford-road—I met a man, told him to stop Moss's van, and I went up to it with Mr. Villmowath—I said to the prisoner, "I want that keg you have got"—he appeared a little

surprised—I said, "Come, let us have it"—he got up and got it down—I still remained with the van, and Mr. Villmowath and the prisoner went into the public-house—I still remained by the van till Mr. Villmowath said, "He is off"—Mr. Villmowath had said at first, "This is a bad job," and the prisoner said, "It is"—I left the keg till the policeman came and took possession of it—this is it—these sized kegs are not so much in use in our manufactory as others are.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What do you know about the prisoner's load on that day? A. I am the party to put what load I consider requisite—I selected the load—I recollect perfectly what it was—I have got a memorandum, which I took at the time of the weights—I have the memo
randum of the weight before it was loaded—I saw them loaded, and counted the quantity put in—there were four large casks and two small ones—that was about half-past eight o'clock in the morning—I waited there till I saw the van drive away—he had six casks—I saw the whole of them loaded—I did not lose sight of the van at any time—I was in the mill-room, and the van was facing it—after the prisoner had got the load all correct, he went away for three or four minutes—there was no person there but myself—when I came up to him, I said, "Now, Moss, I want that keg that you have in the van"—he did not immediately take up the tarpaulin, and take out the keg—he hesitated a few moments, and I said, "Come, hand it out"—I signed my name to this deposition—it was read over to me—I considered it was correct—(read—"I said, 'Now, Moss, I want that keg in your van and he immediately stepped to the head of the van, lifted up the tarpaulin, and took it out")—he did hesitate—I have remembered that all along—I remembered it before the Magistrate.

WILLIAM VILLMOWATH . I superintend the colour-department of Thomas Bradram and others, at Rotherhithe. On 5th Feb., I directed the prisoner to go to be loaded—between eight and nine o'clock Witted came to me respecting this keg of lead—after the conversation I followed the van with Witted, and saw the keg produced by the prisoner—when I first began to follow the van, it was going up the field towards the road—it was in sight of where I was—I followed it just outside the gates of the factory—it was stopped at the public-house, a few yards from the premises—we went up to the van, and Witted said, "I want that keg of lead you have in your van"—the prisoner hesitated a short time, and then lifted up the tarpaulin and produced it, and placed it on one of his casks of white lead—I said, "Moss, this is a very bad job"—he said, "It is," and he wished to return to the factory and wait till Mr. Andrew Bradram came—as there were a crowd of persons come up, I and the prisoner went into the public-house—I came out to get one of the witnesses to bring the keg in—the prisoner followed me out in a leisurely manner, and very shortly afterwards I missed him—I went to the corner of a street a few yards from the spot, and saw him running as fast as he could—the van was put into the care of another carman—the prisoner did not return to the factory—I did not see him till the 17th of May, at the police-court at Greenwich—he had been one of the regular carmen, and been there nearly nine years.

THOMAS ROBERTS (police-sergeant, M 28). On 5th Feb. I was called to Messrs. Brandram's—I saw the van, and on one side of it was this keg of white lead, ten or twelve yards from the gate—I received the keg from Witted—the prisoner had made off—I looked for him, and found him on the 9th of May, standing at the station, talking to the sergeant on duty—he gave the name of William Ward—I told him I should charge him with stealing a

keg of white lead from the premises of his employers—he said, "My name is William Moss, it is all right"—as I went to the Court he remarked, "It is a very bad job, but I dare say they will make a great deal more of it than it deserves."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Four Months.

1221.
WILLIAM TUCKER
, stealing 1,765lbs. weight of leather, value 60l.; the goods of
William Boutcher and others.

JAMBS WILKS . I am warehouseman to Mr. William Boucher and two others. On Monday, 31st Dec, about three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came to their warehouse at Bermondsey—he asked to see some low-priced butts of leather—I showed him two parcels—he selected some, which amounted to 59l. odd—he said, "You will send them in to-morrow morning, and send the invoice with them"—I said, "Yes, but I am not the master; I must have the cash for them on delivery of the goods"—he said, "Well, send them before nine o'clock in the morning; I shall be sure to be at home, and I will give the man the money"—I had sold him a small parcel of goods on the Friday before—that was for cash—it was the first time I had sold to him—after he was gone, I had the leather weighed—next morning I saw the leather loaded, and gave the invoice to Saxby—I told him to be sure to bring back the goods or the money—he left the yard with the goods at a little before eight o'clock, and returned a little after nine without the goods—(I suppose the distance from our place was about a mile and a half)—in consequence of what I heard from him, and by the direction of Mr. Vicary, I went with Saxby and the horse and cart, about eleven o'clock the same morning, to the prisoner's house—I knocked at the front-door, and spoke to a female—in consequence of what she said, I went round to the yard-door, knocked, but no one came—I waited about five minutes—I left Saxby there, and I went round again to the house-door—I knocked twice, and the door was opened by a female—I went in and went through the house into the warehouse—I saw the leather there—one of the parcels contained thirteen bales, of five butts each—I took up one of the bales, and opened the back-gate, and gave the bale to Saxby, who put it into the cart—I went back and attempted to get another bale, but the men in the yard locked the yard-gates; locked the warehouse-door, and locked me in and leather and all—I called to Saxby, who was outside, to come round to the house-door—he came into the house, and I came out and left him in charge—I went back to my employer, and communicated what had happened to Mr. Vicary—it was then about half-past eleven o'clock—I went back to the prisoner's house, and was let in at the front-door by the same female—I waited from half-past four till five—I then saw the prisoner—I asked him why he did not give the man the money as he promised—he said he had been disappointed of some money, and he could not—I said, "Well, then, I must have the goods"—he said that I should neither have goods nor money—I then sent Saxby to my employers, and after some more conversation with the prisoner, on the return of Saxby I sent for a policeman—the policeman said he did not know what it was, whether it was false pretences or a debt, and he could not detain the prisoner—at last, when I found I could not get the policeman to take him, I left—the prisoner told me I might stop as long as I liked, he should neither give me goods nor

money—this was on Tuesday—I went again on Wednesday, and went through into the warehouse—the leather was then gone—they said the prisoner was gone out—I went again on Thursday, and they said he was ill in bed—I went again on Friday—they said he was out of town, and would be home on Saturday, and they had not heard anything of him.

WALTER SAXBY . On Monday, 31st Dec, I assisted Mr. Wilks in weigh
ing the bales of leather—there were thirteen bales of light butts, and three bales of heavy butts—Mr. Wilks took the weights down—these are the cor
rect weights he took down—next morning I went with my master's cart to the prisoner's house in Ann's-place, about eight o'clock—I knocked at the door—a man opened it—I told him I had brought the bales of leather from Boutcher and Co.—he told me to drive round to the back gates—I drove round, and the gates were open—I stopped my cart outside the gates, and two men who were there told me to bring the goods in—I said I could not bring them in till I saw Mr. Tucker—the cart was outside, and I waited in
side—Mr Tucker came in a little while—I showed him the invoice, and told him I had brought the goods, and 1 was to have the money for them; I could not leave them without—I put the invoice into his hand—I never received it back again—he said, "Very well, that is all right, put them down here"—that was inside the gates—I put the goods down, and he said, "They must be weighed"—I assisted in weighing them—he put down the weights on a slate—he did not let me see it, he took it in-doorts, and told me to drive round to the front—I drove round to the front, and the prisoner came to the front and asked me if I should like to have a pint of beer, or a glass of gin, it being a cold morning—I said yes, and he gave me sixpence—that had not the effect of getting me away from the door—I was at the door outside—he shut the door, and said he should be ready for me in a minute or two—in two or three minutes he opened the door, and said there was 21bs. short weight—I believe that would make a difference of 1s. 4d.—I told him I knew nothing about the weight, my orders were to bring the money back, and I must have it or the goods—I said our scales were very correct, and his might make that dif
ference—he said, "Oh, my good man, don't be alarmed, I will go with you in the cart and settle with Mr. Wilks"—that threw me off my guard—he went and got his hat, and got in the cart, and went with me—when we got to the Swan, the prisoner said, "Which way are you going? I am going this way," pointing down Swan-street, which leads to the Grange-road—as soon as he said that he jumped out of the cart over the front—I asked him why he did not come to settle with my master, and I whipped the horse to prevent his getting out, but he got out and went down Swan-street—I went after him, and overtook him about 200 yards off—I asked him why he did not come with me and settle with Mr. Wilks—he turned round and told me not to insult him—I told him I did not insult him, all I wanted was for him to come and settle with Mr. Wilks as he promised—I followed him down as far as the Grange-road, and then be said he would come and settle with Mr. Wilks in an hour—he went on, and I went and told Mr. Wilks—it was then a little past nine—I went to ray breakfast, and on my return, by direction of one of the partners, Mr. Wilks and I took the horse and cart and went to the pri
soner's—we tried to get the leather—we got one bundle, containing five butts, and then were told we should neither have money nor leather, and we came home without money or goods.
Cross-examined by MR. COCKLE. Q. When he got out of the cart did he not tell you he was going to cull on Mr. Edwards, who had disappointed him of a 53l. bill? A. No.

MR. COCKLE to MR. WILKS. Q. Although the prisoner had only dealt with you once before, yet you knew previously that he was in the same business? A. Yes; I had known him as having been in that business about six months—the amount of the order he gave on 31st Dec, was 59l. 6s.—the preceding order was 16l. odd—I believe he paid that in cash in the counting-house—when he said, "Send the invoice with them, "I said, "I am not the master, the goods must be paid for on delivery"—I had no master there at that time—it was a regulation of my own—I had no authority to sell to strangers, except on cash, without my master being there—I had no discretion—I believe 50 pounds of this was recovered from Mr. Welter—the prisoner did not say that he had been disappointed by a Mr. Edwards, who owed him 53l. on a bill of exchange—on 1st Jan., I charged the prisoner with having committed a crime, I sent for the policeman, and be refused to take him in charge.

Q. Did you not say to the prisoner, in the presence of the policeman, after some altercation about this, "Very well, mind, I will take care yon shall have the handle of leather which we took this morning sent back to you, and then if you don't pay on Saturday you will have a writ?" A. No; the prisoner lent out for some gin, and made two glasses of gin-and-water, one for him
self and one for me, but I never touched it—the policeman drank the glass that was made for me—the goods were sent on Tuesday 1st Jan.—I went on the day after—I did not find the prisoner there—I did not see Mr. Weller there any time during that week—I went about eight o'clock each morning—the prisoner was not taken on this charge; he was in Whitecross-street prison for debt before we could find him.

JAMES WILKS
re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner come and pay for the first parcel of goods? A. He did, in the afternoon—the foreman said when the goods went, that Mr. Tucker was gone to our house to pay for them.

WILLIAM LITTLE (policeman, M 118). On Tuesday afternoon, 1st. Jan., I was on duty near the prisoner's house, and was called in about five o'clock—I found the prisoner, the carman, and the prosecutor's foreman—he wanted to give the prisoner in charge, but be seemed to hesitate, first saying he would, and then he would not, saying he wished to have it settled some other way, he wished to come to an arrangement—the prisoner said lie had been disap
pointed, and he should be able to settle the bill on the Saturday following, provided the bundle of leather was returned back which was taken away in the morning—that was agreed to by the prosecutor's foreman, and they shook hands—the foreman replied that he would send the leather back on the morrow morning, and if the whole amount was not paid on the Saturday morning, he should serve him with a writ—the words the foreman said were, "Very good, it shall be done, the leather shall be returned," and if not paid for on Saturday, he should serve him with a writ—after this agreement had been come to, they took some gin-and-water together, and the prosecutor's foreman left the house—they parted in a friendly manner.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I am afraid you have forgotten part; you have not said that you took any gin-and-water? A. No, I did not—I swear that I partook of no gin-and-watch—I was sent for to take this man into custody—Mr. Wilks did not complain that the man had got his master's goods, which he agreed to pay for or return them, and he could neither get goods nor money.
COURT. Q. Then what reason did he give for sending for you? A. He wanted to charge him with obtaining goods under false pretences.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you tell him yon could not take him on that charge? A. No; I was willing to take him, but he seemed to hesitate about charging him—the carman fetched me, I do not know his name—he told me to come to Ann's-place to take a man into custody—he said his master wanted to charge a man; I asked what for, and he said he did not know—I swear he said that—I went with him, and waited there a few moments—there was some conversation—the foreman first said he would charge him, and then he said he would not—I said, If you charge him, you take the responsibility on yourself"—he said he wished to have it settled some other way, he wished to have his money—they had some conversation about the goods—I did not hear exactly what they said—upon my solemn oath I took no gin-and-water.
MR. COCKLE. Q. Is it a regulation that when on duty you are not to drink? A. Yes, we are allowed to drink half-a-pint of beer in the presence of a sergeant.

THOMAS THOMAS . I am an agent, and live at 4, Ely-court, Hatton-garden. I went to the prisoner's house on Tuesday, 1st Jan.—I was admitted through the private house, and was put into his counting-house to wait for him—he was in the house, but was engaged—this was between five and six o'clock—I was able to see from the counting-house into the parlour—there is a slight partition and a glass door—Mr. Tucker was in the parlour, and there other persons; one of them was a policeman, I do not know that I should recog
nize him—I should say that this is the man(Little)—I heard some conver
sation, and I heard some person say, "Remember, if you do not pay the money on Saturday, you will have a writ"—I then saw two persons leave—I know Mr. Edwards; I know the prisoner had a bill on him.

Cross-examined. Q. What about the bill? A. I met Mr. Edwards that morning, and at his request I went to the prisoner about it—I am a commer
cial agent—I have no office—I have no place of business—I do not practise on 'Change—I am a general agent—I have lived at 4, Ely-court, a few weeks—I merely occupy the bedroom there on the ground-floor—I never saw the prisoner till 1st January—about three weeks afterwards I had to go to Whitecross-street prison and I saw him there—I have lived three weeks where I do now—I lived before that at Camden-town—I was coming to town every day—I have the use of part of an office at Mr. Jones's, a wine-merchant, 58, Greek-street, Soho—I am allowed to have my letters addressed there, and to come and write my letters there—before I went to Camden
town I think I lived (upon my word, I almost forget) at 2, Pemberton-row, Gough-square—before that at 21, Tottenham-court, New-road—I was in a situation there, at a wine-merchant's, twelve months.
COURT to WALTER SAXBY. Q. Did you see who drank the gin-and-water? A. I saw the policeman in the passage—he drank out of it—I saw biro drink it—I was in the passage.
Prisoner. The goods were not parted with on the Wednesday.
COURT to JAMES WILKS. Q. When were the goods gone? A. They were gone on the Wednesday morning by eight o'clock.
Prisoner. They were not away till five in the afternoon.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Year.

1222.
EDWARD TINKLER
, embezzling 11 shillings; the moneys of
George Wilton Jordan, his master: to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1223.
WILLIAM BROWN
, stealing 9 pairs of stockings, value 6s.; the goods of
John Weatherby: having been before convicted.

JOHN WEATHERBY . I am a hosier, and live at 90, Lower Marsh, Lambeth. On Saturday night, 11th May, I was fetched to the station-house—I missed about nine pairs of stockings, or it might be a pair or two more—they had been on a shutter under my window—I found my stockings at the station—these are them(produced).

THOMAS JAMES PAINTER . On 11th May, I saw the prisoner passing over the road—I went up to him, and said, "Halloo! what, thieving again"—I took hold of him—he turned, and began to kick and bite me—he dropped these stockings—he struggled to get away—I said, "I know you; you are a regular thief; I had you before"—I held him as long as I could—he fought me in a desperate manner, and had it not been for assistance, I should have lost him—I gave the stockings to the policeman—the prisoner bit me through the knuckle.

BARNETT SIMHONS . I am assistant to my brother, Coleman Simmons, of 93, Lower Marsh, a tin-plate worker. On 11th May, I saw the prisoner go towards Mr. Weatherby's—I told Mr. Painter of it, and while I was talking to him, the prisoner came by with the lot of stockings—Mr. Painter went and took hold of him—he said, "Halloo! what, thieving again"—he bit and kicked Mr. Painter—I came up, and he threw me twice—he would have got away, but the constable came up—he threw the constable twice.

JESSS RUTLAND (police-sergeant, L 28). I took the prisoner—the stockings were brought to the station by Mr. Painter—the prisoner was very Violent; I was obliged to get assistance from another officer.

WILLIAM BROAD (policeman, L 82). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, at Newington—(read—Convicted Jan., 1850, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Year.

1224.
WILLIAM ANDERSON
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; 1 piece of foreign gold coin, 7s.; 11 sovereigns, and 8 half-sovereigns; the property of
William Henry Alldis, from his person.
MESSRS. COCKLE and PRENDERGAST, JUN., conducted the Prosecutions

WILLIAM HENRY ALLDIS . I keep an eating-house, at 10l. Fore-street, Cripplegate. The prisoner came on Saturday, 23rd Feb., with a man named Saunders—he stopped at my counter about a minute—(I had seen Saunders the night previous)—we were very busy, and my waiter asked them to walk up-staire—they did so, and dined—they were up-stairs half or three-quarters of an hour—when they came down they asked if they could speak to me—I told them I could not then, I would in half-an-hour; and I asked them to come back—they said, "No," they would meet me at some neighbouring house—I said, "Next door," which is the Green Dragon—I met them there in half-an-hour—it was then about two o'clock in the day—the prisoner said he had been recommended to me by Saunders, and he had a nephew in the country who was possessed of 2,000l., and he was anxious to get him into business, and he had authorised Saunders to look out for nearly two months, and he knowing my house had recommended him to take it—he said his nephew was about to be married—he asked what I wanted for the house, and what furniture was in it, and I told him—he asked all the particulars that a person could ask if he wanted to take the house—he asked if my servants would stop—I said I did not know; I would ask them—I told him he had better let his nephew see it—he said, "It lies with me entirely," and he said to Saunders, "We must write' to my nephew this afternoon, to that

we shall get him up on Monday morning from Dover"—on Monday, the 25th, we met at the Albion, Blackfriars-road—I got there at four—in half an hour Saunders came—I was drinking a glass of cold sherry and water—in five or ten minutes I saw the prisoner looking in at the window—he came in and said to Saunders, "The moment I sent you out with that letter my niece came in; she came by the train, and I expect my nephew by the seven o'clock train this evening instead of to-morrow"—Saunders had produced a letter to me the moment before the prisoner came; I saw the writing on it—the prisoner then pretended he had dropped his spectacles, and went out for seven or eight minutes—I then said it was no use to wait there any longer, and the meeting was appointed at the same house at seven in the evening—I went there at seven, and found the prisoner—Saunders came in afterwards, and one other, and then a young man, who appeared to be very sober, with a small paper parcel, and the moment after a man who appeared very drunk—the drunken man began to talk—he said he had lost his lady, who had taken something like 2l. from him, but he did not care for that; if he could meet her again he would give her 2l. more—he pulled out a quantity of sovereigns, and said he had been making a bet with a party about throwing a heavy weight, and challenged Saunders—I told him to take no notice of him; we had met there on very different business; and as to throwing weights, I knew nothing about it—Saunders said he had thrown a heavy weight, and he thought he could do it with him, and he should like to try him—the prisoner then said he would go to the Surrey Theatre, and see his wife, who was to meet him there, and see whether his nephew had come up from Dover or no—the young man and the drunken man then left—the prisoner, and Saunders, and me, and the other man, left immediately after to go to the Surrey Theatre—the prisoner proposed going to a beer-shop in Webber-row—when we got there I found the drunken man that I had previously seen, and the other man was leaning over the counter—when we got in they began to talk about their bets, and about throwing heavy weights again—they proposed going to the skittle-ground—eight or ten persons came in from the skittle-ground, and the landlord said, "I have cleared the ground for you to go in"—they all went there, and they said there was nothing heavy enough to throw, but Saunders proposed to play the drunken man at skittles, which he did, and won many pounds of him, and Saunders said to me, "You may as well have 5l. out of this fellow as us; he has been and sold two cows, and you may as well have something"—he nudged me two or three times to put something down, but I would not do it—I had first thought that man was drunk, but afterwards that he was only pretending—I declined having any
thing to do with them—they then began to kick up a dispute about their bets, and shoved up against me several times—I cannot say that the prisoner shoved up against me, but he was near those who did—there were only five in the ground—they served me that way two or three times, and I got in amongst them—I then saw a purse in Saunders's hand—I put my hand into my pocket, and missed my purse—I said, "I have lost my purse out of my pocket"—I had known it was safe perhaps half an hour before—it had con
tained 15l. in sovereigns and half-sovereigns, and a gold Spanish piece—I said, "Why that is my purse," in the company of all of them; and a man got before me, and said, "Don't say that; don't make a noise about it; I shall lose my situation if I am known to be in anything of this"—that was one of the men that met us at the Albion, and accompanied us to the beer-shop—he kept me back, and there was a scuffle with two or three of them on the other side of the frame—the man who appeared so very much intoxicated

took up his coat and went away in his shirt-sleeves—the prisoner and the others went as quickly as possible, leaving me and the man who was speaking to me—he said he knew Saunders, and if I would go with him he would take me to a place where he could find him—when the prisoner and the others went out, I wanted to go past to go after them, but the man would not let me—he said he held a responsible situation, and he would not have it known for the world—in two or three minutes I went out with this man, and he took me to two public-houses—I did not see the prisoner after I got out—I have not seen the last man, who told me he was in a responsible situation, since—this is my purse; I found it behind the boards in the skittle-ground, on the Friday morning following, I think—I had picked up the ring of it on the Monday evening—I know this piece of paper; it was written by the prisoner at the Green Dragon, next door to me—I put it in my purse, but I did not know it was there till the purse was produced—I had not drank anything with the prisoner and the other men; they requested me several times; I refused it—I had not played at skittles or betted—I took my purse out at the Albion—I thought I had some silver in it, and I had not—I put it into my pocket again, and felt in my waistcoat-pocket, and found I had two or three loose shillings—the purse was in my right-hand trowsers-pocket—I gave it and the ring to Goff.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Do I understand you to say, you did not take anything from six o'clock till this occurrence? A. At four o'clock I took a glass of cold sherry and water at the Albion, and the same at seven—I never saw the man who keeps the beer-shop before—I under
stand his name is Dickinson—I left the beer-shop at half-past ten—I came back again that night—I saw the landlord in the bar when I was going out at half-past ten—I did not speak to him, nor be to me—I have seen Saunders since in custody—I appeared against him at the police-office—he was dis
charged by the Magistrate—he was the very man in whose hand I had seen the purse—I found the puree on the Friday—I had not been to the house between the Monday and the Friday, and I never was there before the Mon
day—the man who kept me back described himself as a lawyer—we were the last two that went out—we did not talk at all at the bar—we went right out—I came back again that night with the same man—I spoke to the landlord, and asked him if he knew either of those men that came in—he said, "No."

Q. Did he not ask you if there was anything the matter, and did you not say "No?"A. I do not recollect that—1 swear he did not ask me what was the matter—I did not say, "No, nothing particular"—I went with the policeman to the skittle-ground on the Friday following—I never said I found it as the people were going out, and they fell—I went with the two policemen to the end of the ground, and saw the purse among some straw, where I saw the man fall—the landlord was not there then—the officer showed the land
lord the purse in my presence—it was found behind some boards six or eight inches thick, and there is straw behind them—it was in a place between the boards that you might put your band—1 was the first to find it—I saw the landlord again on the Monday night—I went back once after I had left it—that party stopped with me, and persuaded me to take a cab and go home—I gave him my address—I gave information next day, Tuesday, to the City In
spector of the Ward of Cripplegate—I think Saunders was taken the week following—I appeared twice against him—he was remanded, and was dis
charged the last time—this prisoner was not in custody then; he was not to be found—when the purse was produced, the landlord did not say anything to me—he did not say, "It is rather singular to find the purse there; I was

there a quarter of an hour ago, and saw no purse there"—I did not go to the house between the Monday and Friday; I was afraid—I went on the Friday morning—I do not recollect whether the policemen were in plain clothes, or in uniform—three men went into the beer-shop with me, and we found two there—they might have been half an hour or three-quarters playing at skit
tles—the prisoner said his wife was to be at the Albion at nine o'clock, and the time was expired, and he would go and look for her—I did not speak to any policeman that night—I got home about half-past eleven—I did not men
tion my loss to my wife, or to any one that night—I have been married twenty years—I did not wish to let her know my loss.

MR. COCKLE. Q. Have you any doubt as to the purse being found behind the boards? A. No; I have never said I had—there is no foundation, for what has been asked about what was said by the landlord—I was afraid to go back to the house, because I have heard such an account of the characters who frequent it—I went to the police next day, after I had done my business, about five or six o'clock in the evening—I did not complain to the landlord that night, because I was led to believe that the party who was stopping behind was my friend—he said he knew where to find Saunders, and would take me to the places.

FRANCIS ELEY . I was waiter to Mr. Alldis. The prisoner came to Mr. Alldis with Saunders—I had no conversatiop with the prisoner—Saun
ders said, "Good morning" when they came—I had seen him on the 22nd with a female.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant, L 8). Alldis came to me on Wednesday, 27th Feb.—he gave me this broken ring (produced)—on 1st March I went with him by appointment to the Flying Horse beer-shop, kept by Mr. Dickinson—we went into the skittle-ground, and I saw him put his hand in, and take this purse out from between two pieces of wood, which are put to keep the skittle-balls from going out—I took it out of his hand; this piece of paper was in it—there was only one ring on it—the broken ring given me by Alldis corresponded with it—I had spoken to the landlord before we went in the ground—I sent an officer to him—he came, and I showed it him in the skittle-ground, and pointed out the place to him where it had been found—the landlord, Alldis, and I, were in the skittle-ground together for seven or ten minutes.

Cross-examined. Q. You have before said that Alldis cried out to you, "Look here?" A. Yes, he did; I could not see anything, but he put his hand between two pieces of wood, and took the purse out—the landlord was not there then, but the officer Garford was—we did not separate in the ground—we went to a door, and then along the right-hand side of the frame till we came to the top—then Alldis went on to the top, and he said, "Look here!"—I had not searched—we looked about as we went—there were no persons in the skittle-ground—we showed the purse to the landlord—I do not re
member that he said anything—he did not say to me that it was very queer—I heard him say that the persons that were there paid him 3s. for the use of the ground, and that Alldis did not play—he did not say to Alldis, in my presence, "Why did you not tell me when I asked you if anything was the matter?"—I saw Alldis on Wednesday, and made an appointment to meet him on the Friday—I was in plain clothes, but I was well known at the house.

WILLIAM HENRY ALLDIS
re-examined. This is the piece of paper that was in my purse—the prisoner wrote it in the Green Dragon, "Meet me on Monday, at four o'clock, at the foot of Blackfriars-bridge"—he gave it me on the Saturday afternoon—I know it is his writing, but I should know the purse without that—this was in the purse when I lost it, and when I found it.
Cross-examined. Q. Is there any mark on the purse? A. No; one of my own children knitted it for me—it is torn—it was not torn when I lost it.

HENRY JOHN DICKINSON . I live at 1, Webber-street, Blackfriars-rotd, and am a beer-shop keeper. On the night of 25th Feb. the prisoner came to my house by himself—Alldis came with a man named Saunders—the prisoner came in after them, and had a glass of something to drink; and hearing the skittles go, he asked me if there was anybody in the skittle-ground—I said, "Yes, I think there is"—the prisoner went into the skittle-ground—I served the persons in the skittle-ground with a pot of ale—I was not paid for it then—I should say there were five or six persons in the skittle-ground—in half an hour another pot of ale was called for, and a cheroot—I took them in—I was not paid then for them; but as Mr. Saunders and Mr. Alldis went out, Mr. Saunders put the money down—Mr. Alldis went out an hour, or a little less, after he came in—Mr. Saunders and several others that were in the ground went out with him—they all came out together, and Mr. Saunders and Mr. Alldis stopped behind, and put down 3s. for me to take my reckoning—they never stopped to take the change—I saw Mr. Aldis again that night, in about a quarter of an hour afterwards—the prisoner was with him—Mr. Alldis said to me, "Are you the proprietor of this house?"—I said, "I am"—he said, "Do you know this man?"—I said he might have been in, and had a glass of ale, but I did not know him—I said to Mr. Alldis, "What is the matter?"—he said, "Nothing of any consequence;" and they both went away together—this was on the Monday; and on Tuesday morning I saw Mr. Alldis again—he had two policemen with him—Goff asked if they could go and have a game at skittles—I said, yes, if they liked—they went and played for a pint of ale; and while they were playing, Goff came running to me, and said, "Look here what we have found in the skittle-ground"—I will not say for certain whether that was on the Tuesday or on the Friday—it was the next time I saw him—Goff came to me with this purse in his hand—they pointed out to me where it had been found—I said it was a very curious thing, when a quarter of an hour before I was looking in that very hole for a hammer, and I saw no purse there—any persons who were in the skittle-ground could very easily see the purse in the place in which it was found—I have many persons come into the skittle-ground in the course of a week.

Cross-examined by MR. COCKLE. Q. Had you ever seen. Mr. Alldis before that night? A. Never; he had never been in my shop that I know of—the prisoner might have been there before, but not that I am aware of—I had seen Saunders before, he is a neighbour of mine—I saw no man come in with Alldis but Saunders—after they were in the skittle-ground, I went in and asked if there were any orders—the prisoner was not there then, to my recollection—he came in in a quarter of an hour, asked for a glass of ale, and asked if there was any playing—I told him, "Yes"—I did not see the pri
soner and Mr. Alldis in conversation—I should say there were five or six persons in the skittle-ground—there was a man sticking up skittles—there were several persons that I had seen before in the skittle-ground—they had two pots of ale and some cheroots—it came to 1s. 8d. or 2s.—they put down 3s.—I said, "You will take your change"—they went away without waiting for change—they never said that what was paid over and above was for clear
ing the skittle-ground; I did not understand so—I have been fined for having two men playing at cards—one of them turned out to be a thief afterwards, but I was not aware of it—I remember giving bail for a man named George Green—he was committed for picking pockets at Greenwich—I was bail for him, and I would for anybody else in distress.

Q. Has there not been a similar transaction to this when Mr. Raby, a broker in Kent-street, was robbed in your skittle-ground of 10l? A. I heard of it—I do not know whether his name was Raby—I was never charged with having anything to do with it—I was never charged respecting the robbery of Mr. Sexton, who was robbed of 25l. in my house—I know there is such a man as Mr. Sexton, but I do not recollect his coming to my place—if he was robbed it was unknown to me—when Alldis and Goff came next morning, I asked him if there was anything wrong—he said, "Yes, I think there is something wrong"—I asked him what was the matter—he said, "I have been robbed of my purse"—Goff was not present; he was gone, and his friend, to play a game at skittles—I said to Alldis, "How came you to lose your purse?"—he said, "The last pot of ale you brought was drugged; I was the only person that drank of it, and the rest was chucked into the next ground"—I do not think Goff was present when he said this; he was gone through to have a game at skittles—now I come to recollect, I think the policeman was present when he said he had been drugged in the ground—the policeman said, "I want to have a game at skittles"—I said, "You can go if you like"—they went, and I thought they had been there long enough—I went in, and they called for a pint of ale, and then he cane and said he had found a purse.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. He was out about a quarter of an hour, and came back with the prisoner? A. Yes; I said, "What is the matter?"—he said, "Never mind; no consequence; nothing particular," and he went away—the next time he came with the policeman, and then he said he had lost his purse and he was drugged, and the rest of the ale was chucked over into the next ground.
(The prisoner received a good character).
GUILTY .

1225.
WILLIAM ANDERSON was again indicted
for stealing 30 sove
reigns, 20 half-sovereigns, and 1 10l. bank-note; the property of
Robert Catton: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1226.
DANIEL MURPHY
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 4s.; the goods of
William Simpson, from his person.

JOHN SIMPSON . On 12th June I was passing along High-street, in the Borough—when near the Town-hall, I felt a tug at my pocket—I turned, and saw the prisoner and another boy—the prisoner had my handkerchief in his hand—I laid hold of him, and gave him in charge—I had my handkerchief safe, and had used it six or seven minutes before—this is it.
SAMUEL CROSS (policeman, M 83). The prisoner was given in my charge, and this handkerchief.

p.rs: GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p:
1227.
JOHN LAWRENCE,
AMELIA CALLON , and
CATHARINE DAY
, stealing 2 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 4 crowns, 7 shillings, and 14 sixpences; the moneys of
Robert Holmes; from his person.

ROBERT HOLMES . I am a mariner—I was paid off on 12th June, about two o'clock, and received 5l. in sovereigns—I went over to Tooley-street, and paid a few shillings that I owed—I went to the Paddington station with my luggage—I dropped down from the buss at the Bank—about nine o'clock in the evening I was proceeding from the Bank towards London-bridge—I met the three prisoners in company—I had my blue jacket on—my money was in my trowsers pocket—the prisoners spoke to me, and asked me to take them

into a public-house—I took them into a public-house on the north side of the water in the City—I cannot say what public-house it was—they went into the house first and I followed them—the house was their choice—we had two half-pints of gin there—we went over the bridge, went into another public-house, and had two half-pints more—I was then very much intoxicated—I cannot recollect whether I consented to go home with the prisoners, but I consented to go in a cab—I had ray money then—I put my hand into my pocket, and felt the money safe when I was in the public-home, and when I got into the cab—I had paid for one half-pint of spirits, and the prisoner Lawrence paid for the other—I was not with any persons but the prisoners from the time my money was safe—while I was in the cab, I put my hand into my pocket, and missed my money—I put out my hands and seized the cab doors, and said I had been robbed, and no one should go out till I had a policeman—I sung out, and there came two policemen, and the prisoners were taken to the station—I suspected I had lost my money in the cab, as the prisoners began to hustle me about.

JOSIAH WELCH (policeman, M 282). About half-past eleven o'clock at night, on the 12th of June, I was on duty at Newington-causeway—I heard a cry of "Police!" from a cab—I went to one door and called another police
man, who went to the other door—I found the three prisoners and the prose
cutor in the cab—he stood with one of his hands on each door, and said, "I have been robbed of 2l. or 3l."—we took them to the station—the women said they did not know anything about it—the man said he supposed that because the prosecutor saw him flashing his money, he said he had been robbed—I found 3l. 9s. 2 1/2d. on the man—the women were searched—there was only six duplicates found on them—they had no money—the prosecutor was in liquor, but his senses were not gone.
Lawrence's Defence. It was my own money, and he swore it was his; I paid for something to drink, and he says he paid for the buss, and I paid for it.

Callon's Defence. I am not guilty; I do not know this man no more than I do the sailor; they went and had a quartern of gin, and came over the bridge and had a pot of ale, I did not sit near the sailor when he lost his money.

LAWRENCE—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

CALLON—
GUILTY .

DAY—
GUILTY .

1228.
SARAH ANN SAUNDERS
, stealing 1 gown, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Henry Hamshare.

HENRY HAMSHARE . I live in Batteraea-fields. On 5th June, I had some clothes hanging in front of my door—I saw the prisoner come in at the garden-gate, and take a gown from the line—she was going to take it away in her lap—I followed her, and asked her what she did it for—she said she did it for bread—this is the gown—I gave it to a policeman.
JOHN SPICE (policeman, V 43). I took the gown and the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. It is not a garden, but a brewer's yard, which is open to anybody; I went in to speak to one of the men; I had some cabbages in my apron; the prosecutor said they were stolen, and he supposed I had more stolen property about me; but he shook hands with me and bid me good
bye; about twenty minutes afterwards he came back and took me; I never saw the gown.
NOT GUILTY .

1229.
HANNAH PEPPIN
, stealing 3 yards of lace, 2 yards of ribbon, and other articles, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Eliza Mary Nicholls, her mis
tress: to which she pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: [The following was omitted among the Middlesex Cases:]

div1.p:
1230.
GEORGE LEWIS
, stealing 1 seal, 1 brequet chain, and 1 watch, key, value 1l. 2s.; the goods of
Harriett Jane Butler; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JULY 8TH, 1850.
